Velká čísla spojená s velkými technologickými firmami stačí k tomu, aby mnoho investorů znervóznělo. Možná největším rizikem pro mimořádnou výkonnost tohoto sektoru ale není jeho rozsah, nýbrž vyhlídky pro zotavování ekonomiky, napsala v komentáři pro Financial Times analytička Société Générale Sophie Huynh. Velká jména z technologického sektoru tvoří skoro čtvrtinu hodnoty celého indexu S&P 500 a zhruba polovinu v Nasdaq 100 . S&P 500 by byl bez Big Tech letos zatím nižší zhruba o 6 %, a ne přibližně na svém, jak je tomu nyní. Měli by investoři být nervózní kvůli samotné valuaci těchto firem? Historie ukazuje, že nikoli. Podle analýzy Hendrika Bessembindera z Arizona State University nejlépe performující 4 % listovaných společností poháněla čistý zisk celého amerického trhu s akciemi už od roku 1926. Valuace sahající až do nebes dávají docela velký smysl, domnívá se analytička. Podnikatelské modely těchto firem a postupná digitalizace každodenního života jsou jenom jedním faktorem, který napomohl jejich úspěchu. Hromadění peněz v rozvahách jim umožnilo zpětné odkupy akcií a jejich mimořádné ziskové marže podepřely silný růst jejich akcií. Toto vše v době, kdy rozdílnost mezi silnými a slabými rozvahami nikdy nebyla zásadnější. Zavírání ekonomiky kvůli Covid-19 urychlilo strukturální trendy, jako je práce z domova a nákupy přes internet. No a ještě nižší úrokové sazby (navíc k 16 bilionům dolarů v investičním státním a korporátním dluhu se záporným výnosem) udělaly z akciového univerza ještě lákavější třídu aktiv. Valuace tlačila nahoru i nižší diskontní sazba. Investoři, kteří hledali ochranu pro svoje portfolio, měli jen málo na výběr, protože desetileté americké výnosy (zamrzlé mezi 0,5 až 0,7 %) pro ně asi nemohly být volbou. Toto vše vysvětluje, proč akcie amerických technologických firem vedly od 23. března zotavování akciového trhu. Urychlil to určitě i přiliv drobných investorů, sázka na momentum a syndrom FOMO – strach, že něco zmeškáme. Pokud budou trhy setrvávat v nervozitě, bude Big Tech pravděpodobně v přízni. Představa, že prezidentské volby v USA skončí sporem nebo opožděným výsledkem, nadále dává trumfy růstovým aktivům a defenzivním segmentům globálního akciového trhu. Obavy, že Big Tech se zhroutí pod vlastní vahou, asi tedy nejsou na místě. Nelze ovšem říct, že by odvětví nemělo svoje slabá místa. Podle analytičky by si investoři měli dávat pozor na hospodářské vyhlídky a regulaci. Možná to bude znít paradoxně, ale největší hrozbou by pro ně mohl být optimističtější ekonomický obrázek. Pokud se objeví známky účinné vakcíny, normalizace globálního hospodářského růstu by účastníky trhu pravděpodobně přiměla k tomu, že by začali hledat začátek nového minicyklu. To by mohlo vést k rotaci a odstartovat diverzifikaci směrem k necykličtějším částem akciového vesmíru – a tedy z Big Tech. Takovýto scénář by asi prospěl indexu středních firem S&P 400 MidCap, ale i akciím v eurozóně a na rozvíjejících se trzích. Kromě toho tu je také ostřejší drobnohled regulátorů a politiků, kteří mají na programu zvyšování daní. Ani to by nepomohlo. Za možné spouštěče nějaké relativně horší výkonnosti to sice v SocGen nepovažují. Mohlo by to ale poškodit historii jejich silné, o riziko očištěné návratnosti, kterou Big Tech mají. Kromě toho roste šance, že v americkém volebním roce se na technologie zaměří další politici. Výsledkem by mohl být větší regulační tlak. Velké ekonomiky napříč OECD mezitím pracují na návrzích, které by mohly změnit prostředí zdanění. Loni v lednu se 129 zemí včetně USA rámcově shodlo na digitální dani. A podle tohoto návrhu by otázka digitálního zdanění měla přijít na přetřes ještě do konce tohoto roku. Obavy ze zhroucení rally v Big Tech jsou možná mimo mísu. Investoři, kteří vzhlížejí k průlomu v souvislosti s koronavirem, by se ale měli raději dívat někam jinam, konstatuje v závěru analytička. Zdroj

Velká čísla spojená s velkými technologickými firmami stačí k tomu, aby mnoho investorů znervóznělo. Možná největším rizikem pro mimořádnou výkonnost tohoto sektoru ale není jeho rozsah, nýbrž vyhlídky pro zotavování ekonomiky, napsala v komentáři pro Financial Times analytička Sophie Huynh. Velká jména z technologického sektoru tvoří skoro čtvrtinu hodnoty celého indexu S&P 500 a zhruba polovinu v Nasdaq 100 . S&P 500 by byl bez Big Tech letos zatím nižší zhruba o 6 %, a ne přibližně na svém, jak je tomu nyní. Měli by investoři být nervózní kvůli samotné valuaci těchto firem? Historie ukazuje, že nikoli. Podle analýzy Hendrika Bessembindera z Arizona State University nejlépe performující 4 % listovaných společností poháněla čistý zisk celého amerického trhu s akciemi už od roku 1926. Valuace sahající až do nebes dávají docela velký smysl, domnívá se analytička. Podnikatelské modely těchto firem a postupná digitalizace každodenního života jsou jenom jedním faktorem, který napomohl jejich úspěchu. Hromadění peněz v rozvahách jim umožnilo zpětné odkupy akcií a jejich mimořádné ziskové marže podepřely silný růst jejich akcií. Toto vše v době, kdy rozdílnost mezi silnými a slabými rozvahami nikdy nebyla zásadnější. Zavírání ekonomiky kvůli Covid-19 urychlilo strukturální trendy, jako je práce z domova a nákupy přes internet. No a ještě nižší úrokové sazby (navíc k 16 bilionům dolarů v investičním státním a korporátním dluhu se záporným výnosem) udělaly z akciového univerza ještě lákavější třídu aktiv. Valuace tlačila nahoru i nižší diskontní sazba. Investoři, kteří hledali ochranu pro svoje portfolio, měli jen málo na výběr, protože desetileté americké výnosy (zamrzlé mezi 0,5 až 0,7 %) pro ně asi nemohly být volbou. Toto vše vysvětluje, proč akcie amerických technologických firem vedly od 23. března zotavování akciového trhu. Urychlil to určitě i přiliv drobných investorů, sázka na momentum a syndrom FOMO – strach, že něco zmeškáme. Pokud budou trhy setrvávat v nervozitě, bude Big Tech pravděpodobně v přízni. Představa, že prezidentské volby v USA skončí sporem nebo opožděným výsledkem, nadále dává trumfy růstovým aktivům a defenzivním segmentům globálního akciového trhu. Obavy, že Big Tech se zhroutí pod vlastní vahou, asi tedy nejsou na místě. Nelze ovšem říct, že by odvětví nemělo svoje slabá místa. Podle analytičky by si investoři měli dávat pozor na hospodářské vyhlídky a regulaci. Možná to bude znít paradoxně, ale největší hrozbou by pro ně mohl být optimističtější ekonomický obrázek. Pokud se objeví známky účinné vakcíny, normalizace globálního hospodářského růstu by účastníky trhu pravděpodobně přiměla k tomu, že by začali hledat začátek nového minicyklu. To by mohlo vést k rotaci a odstartovat diverzifikaci směrem k necykličtějším částem akciového vesmíru – a tedy z Big Tech. Takovýto scénář by asi prospěl indexu středních firem S&P 400 MidCap, ale i akciím v eurozóně a na rozvíjejících se trzích. Kromě toho tu je také ostřejší drobnohled regulátorů a politiků, kteří mají na programu zvyšování daní. Ani to by nepomohlo. Za možné spouštěče nějaké relativně horší výkonnosti to sice v SocGen nepovažují. Mohlo by to ale poškodit historii jejich silné, o riziko očištěné návratnosti, kterou Big Tech mají. Kromě toho roste šance, že v americkém volebním roce se na technologie zaměří další politici. Výsledkem by mohl být větší regulační tlak. Velké ekonomiky napříč OECD mezitím pracují na návrzích, které by mohly změnit prostředí zdanění. Loni v lednu se 129 zemí včetně USA rámcově shodlo na digitální dani. A podle tohoto návrhu by otázka digitálního zdanění měla přijít na přetřes ještě do konce tohoto roku. Obavy ze zhroucení rally v Big Tech jsou možná mimo mísu. Investoři, kteří vzhlížejí k průlomu v souvislosti s koronavirem, by se ale měli raději dívat někam jinam, konstatuje v závěru analytička. Zdroj

urn:contentItem:60RY-H2S1-F021-62HJ-00000-00FTSE 100 is worth more than Apple again after it plunged 8% to £1.6trillion as US tech stocks tumbled dragging down value of Microsoft, Google and Amazon2020-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:43ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1FTSE 100 is worth more than Apple again after it plunged 8% to £1.6trillion as US tech stocks tumbled dragging down value of Microsoft, Google and AmazonMark Duell for MailOnlineFrancesca Washtell For The Daily Mail

Apple fell 8% in New York yesterday which valued compmany at £1.55trillion

This is slightly below FTSE 100 fell 1.5% to finish at a total value of £1.61trillion

This means iPhone manufacture is now worth slightly less than all 100 UK firms

On Tuesday Apple rose above FTSE value but suffered yesterday in a tech sell off

Apple has fallen back below the value of the FTSE 100 as UK investors were caught in the crosshairs of a massive sell-off in technology stocks that rocked US markets.

The California-based company dropped 8 per cent or $10 (£7.52) to close at $120.88 (£90.95) in New York yesterday as traders took their money and ran. This marked a $180billion (£135billion) fall in market value, the largest ever in one day for a US firm.

The dive gave Apple a valuation of $2.07trillion (£1.55trillion) - slightly below the FTSE 100 which finished at £1.61trillion after falling 1.5 per cent, or 90 points, to 5851.

This means the iPhone manufacture is now worth slightly less than all 100 UK firms, which together employ five million people compared to the 137,000 Apple staff.

It came two days after Apple overtook the entire FTSE 100 value on Tuesday after the manufacturer's share price surged during the coronavirus pandemic. At that stage it was worth $2.2trillion (£1.65trillion), compared to the FTSE at £1.63trillion.

Yesterday's falls took place as shares in other technology giants on Wall Street such as Amazon, Google's Alphabet and Microsoft also dropped by more than 4 per cent.

Analysts said there seemed to be no explicit catalyst for the sell-off, with economic data coming in roughly where the market had expected and no companies issuing foreboding warnings - but they suggested the market was just due for a breather.

Simon French, chief economist for Panmure Gordon, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme this morning: 'We need to put those moves into context.

'Those companies (Apple, Amazon, Alphabet and Microsoft) collectively at the start of September, were up 57 per cent year to date.

'And that is in contrast to the Dow Jones industrial Average of more traditional US companies which is down 2 per cent on the year.

'So I think it was a case of investors taking some money off the table for some of these tech stocks, given some very, very sky high valuations and a great run.

'But also there will also be concerns that tall poppies attract attention from regulators and potentially with a US presidential election coming up in November, and lawmakers questioning whether they have too much market dominance.'

Yesterday's tumble wiped 5 per cent off the Nasdaq and marked an abrupt halt in a rally over the past few months that has taken the stock markets to record highs.

Before yesterday, Apple had seen its price rise by more than 75 per cent since the start of 2020, while the FTSE 100 had fallen by 23 per cent this year.

Investors have been attracted to Apple's stock amid hopes it would benefit from high consumer demand in lockdown as people switched to working from home.

On Tuesday, Apple rose just under 4 per cent after a report that the company had asked suppliers to make at least 75million 5G iPhones for later this year.

It was also boosted by a four-for-one stock split that made its shares more affordable to more investors, which was first announced five weeks ago.

The company cut each $500 (£375) share into four $125 (£95) shares, saying it did so for a broader base of investors to afford to buy its stock.

Last month Apple, which is the world's biggest company by market capitalisation, become the first US firm to boast a market value of $2trillion (£1.5trillion).

That milestone came just two years after the firm became the first to reach $1trillion (£0.75trillion).

This year the firm has overcome the shutdown of factories in China that produce the iPhone and the closure of its retail sales amid the Covid-19 crisis.

The company has a hugely loyal customer base which continued to buy iPhones and other devices online while stuck at home during the lockdown.

During the pandemic Apple gained about $6.7billion (£5billion) in value every business day - the equivalent of adding a Rolls-Royce every day to its market cap.

Apple reported an 11 per cent increase in quarterly revenue in July with sales up to $59.7billion (£44.8billion), but said its new iPhone 12 had been delayed.

Apple has been at the vanguard of a group of Big Tech companies that are increasingly taking over people's lives - and the stock market in the US.

Just five companies - Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Facebook and Google's parent company - account for nearly 23 per cent of the S&P 500's entire value.

Saudi Aramco reached a market value of $2trillion shortly after becoming a public company in December 2019, although it has fallen since amid a drop in oil prices.

Apple is said to be preparing to ship 75million new iPhone 12 models this year with the company hoping sales of the next-generation iPhone reach 80million.

The initial figures are in line with previous iPhone launches, suggesting Apple does not think the crisis and economic slowdown are causing consumer interest to wane.

The company is planning to launch four iPhone 12 models later this year with different screen sizes, 5G support and crisp OLED displays.

Apple is also preparing a new iPad Air with an edge-to-edge screen, two new versions of the Apple Watch and a smaller and cheaper HomePod speaker.

urn:contentItem:41JH-9480-00W3-V00G-00000-00FTSE 350: Top Company Recommendations - Which Companies And Sectors Have Been2000-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:43ZLexisNexisPg. 30,31,32,33,34,35,36,37,40,41,42,43,44,45,46,47,48FTSE 350: Top Company Recommendations - Which Companies And Sectors Have Been

Regular readers of investors chronicle will be familiar with our snapshots of the 350 biggest listed companies in the UK. This guide is designed to allow you to follow the fortunes of your shares and their sectors quickly and easily. Whether you hold the shares or not, the FTSE 350 guide is designed to give you enough information to decide what you should do now - buy, sell or hold.

We've rummaged through all 350 companies and picked out the most interesting stories to highlight in each sector, along with an overview of the sector. We've also provided key information on each company (latest share price, market value, PE and dividend yield) plus a reminder of what the IC's view of the company was at the time of its last published results.

Since the start of this year the FTSE 350 index has been going nowhere. On 18 October, the index was down almost 10 per cent since 1 January 2000.

Between 1 January 1999 and 18 October, it rose by 8.25 per cent, hardly enough to make investors drool at the mouth and only a fraction more than many instant access savings and current accounts are paying.

Of course, hidden behind this year's poor show so far for the combined performance of the top 350 companies are sharp movements in the share prices of individual companies and whole sectors. Investors who picked the right shares at the right time are now sitting on first-class gains.

The strongest climbers over the period were biotech Cambridge Antibody with returns in excess of 464 per cent, followed by Oxford GlycoSciences which notched up a gain of more than 400 per cent.

Biotechs account for four out of five of the top risers over the period (Celltech and Shire Pharmaceuticals are the other two), giving the lie to the notion that all biotechs are loss-making disaster zones. But also found among the top 20 risers are unloved retailers and household and toiletry product makers. Matalan, the discount clothing chain, rose by 82.8 per cent and Reckitt Benckiser jumped 64.5 per cent.

British Telecom, Stagecoach and Eidos, all erstwhile darlings of the market, shed more than 50 per cent of their value. Eidos lost 77 per cent of its value and only narrowly avoided being the worst performing stock over the whole period - it was pipped by Atlantic Telecom, with a fall of 77.9 per cent, not a great record for its first year as a constituent of the FTSE 350.

The net effect of wild gyrations in telecom, software and IT stocks was to push those sectors right down to the bottom of the sector performance table - only steel did worse. Software and computer services fell by 33 per cent between 1 January and 18 October 2000 (against a gain of 165 per cent for the whole of 1999) while telecom services dropped 36.6 per cent. construction/housebuilding

Housebuilders have had a great year so far. Prices soared in the first six months, pushing profits and margins forward, and the slowdown shows no sign of accelerating into a full-scale recession for the moment. But the market isn't convinced and the shares are unlikely to move far from their lowly ratings until the City is persuaded that interest rates have peaked and profits are sustainable.

PE ratios for the FTSE 350 crowd range from a dismal four for Wimpey to a slightly less dismal eight for sector leaders like Redrow and Berkeley. As well as destroying shareholder value, low ratings make fund-raising difficult. Some of the companies have had enough, and Redrow has joined smaller players like Linden and Fairview in considering a stock market exit. The company has started the ball rolling with a 30 per cent share buy-back, but chief executive Paul Pedley has indicated that he'll take the company private if things don't improve in the next couple of years.

Operationally, the aim for many of the housebuilders is to catch up with leaders like Berkeley, with its London focus, and Wilson Bowden which makes good use of a healthy long-term land bank. At the other end of the scale, Wimpey's margins languish at 8 per cent but there are plans to improve this through cost cutting and improving the land bank. Labour shortages are hitting all housebuilders, prompting some to start using manufactured components like timber frames in their houses.

Margin improvement is also an aim for the contractors which have traditionally been plagued by wafer thin margins. The idea is to cut out competitive bidding and only work on contracts where there is a long-term relationship with the client. sector snapshots - paper & packaging

The packaging industry has been in the doldrums for many years. Investors' antipathy towards the sector has meant that many companies have been bought up by foreign competitors. In order to compete companies have been doubling up in their core businesses to gain critical mass or exiting altogether. The weak euro has also given European competitors an advantage in the UK and made it more difficult for UK companies to export in Europe.

pharmaceuticals and healthcare

Glaxo Wellcome's GBP 120bn merger with SmithKline Beecham - creating the world's biggest pharmaceutical company by sales - should have been the sector's story of the year. But the real stars of 2000 have been the biotechs.

A constellation of companies hit the stock market equivalent of the jackpot following years of investor indifference. When we last reviewed the FTSE 350 back in January it had just six pharmaceutical companies. Industry figures were full of gloom. Clinical progress was going unnoticed, raising capital was hellishly difficult and all the while cashpiles were dwindling. The FTSE 350 now boasts 10 pharma stocks following breakthroughs by Cambridge Antibody Technology and Oxford GlycoSciences, and reratings of SkyePharma and Biocompatibles.

Safety needle maker Medisys also joined the FTSE 350 after a spectacular time on Aim.

What's changed the fortunes of these biotech companies - and made the fortunes of many more investors - has been a combination of two things.

On the one hand, from February onwards the boom in information-technology stocks began to spread to biotechnology as well. Institutional and private investors who had made a packet from internet or telecom shares began to move into budding biotech companies. Having successfully risked and won, they spied fresh fields of enterprise.

On the other hand, the wider biotech endeavour took some significant strides forward, helping to convince investors that the science behind it could really deliver. In essence, the biotechnology approach to medicine can be defined as discovering how the body works at the levels of genes and proteins and then using this knowledge to understand how diseases happen.

In June US president Bill Clinton and UK prime minister Tony Blair announced that scientists had completed a first draft of the entire human genome. It was a hugely symbolic achievement. Of more practical significance were the launches of the new generation antibody-based drugs, including Celltech's Mylotarg for acute myeloid leukaemia.

As biotechnology began to prove its worth, the City ratcheted up expectations of what it might eventually achieve. The biggest winners were companies closest to the cutting edge of genomics. Shares in Cambridge Antibody Technology and Oxford GlycoSciences exploded because of each company's ability to speed up the development of new drugs.

They both announced a string of development pacts with big pharma and US biotech firms, as well as advancing their own compounds through clinical trials.

Meanwhile Glaxo and SmithKline inched towards their merger. European regulators quickly gave the all clear. However, the minute examination of the deal by US antitrust authorities - which still isn't finished - must have left thousands of researchers and middle managers in limbo.

AstraZeneca, by contrast, has enjoyed a good few months. Shares had been weighed down by concerns about Losec, its blockbuster ulcer drug that is losing patent protection in the US next year. It's hauling generic competitors through the courts wherever possible while spending millions of pounds launching Nexium, its improved version of Losec. However, third- quarter figures this week suggest that sales of Nexium are taking off more slowly than expected. sector snapshots - investment banks

- Close Brothers' market making arm, Winterflood, looks in good shape; asset management and corporate finance are firing on all cylinders too. The business was certainly boosted by the acquisition of Rea Brothers; that deal quadrupled funds managed to GBP 2.6bn. Close is one of the last merchant banks left but with this kind of growth profile it looks well paced to go it alone.

Good value (1,208p, 6 October 2000)

- It's the investment book that dominates market sentiment in Durlacher and, not surprisingly, the bank's shares took a mighty big punch after the technology sector collapsed. Still with earnings rocketing ahead it's hard to fault the performance. And now that the company is doing a joint venture with Germany's bmp, expect Durlacher to take an increasing interest in life science investments.

Good value (94p, 22 September 2000)

- Singer & Friedlander is selling its Swedish stockbroker, Carnegie. Ditching that highly profitable operation might look odd, but it will slash costs and make the bank more focused. Brokers also think that Carnegie might be worth about GBP 700m; add Singer's chunk of that to the cash from selling Collins Stewart and subtract the total from S&F's market cap and the core bank looks undervalued.

Good value (286p, 8 September 2000)

engineering

Having struggled for the last two years against the high rate of sterling and its old economy image, the UK engineering sector is now threatening to make a comeback. Since the high-tech shake-out in March the FTSE 350 engineering sector has risen by 1.77 per cent, outperforming the general 350 by 4.56 per cent. However despite its recent modest outperformance, analysts urge caution, arguing that while many engineering shares appear cheap in a majority of cases the depressed levels are fully justified. Many engineering companies are highly exposed to the strength of the US economy - which accounts for around 50 per cent of the sector's sales - and the recent slowdown of the US housing and automotive markets has already led to a slowdown in sales at Tomkins. ABN Amro engineering analyst Guy Hewett looks for companies which serve markets detached from the general US industrial sector or whose valuation is rock bottom. In the former group Hewett identifies BBA, which provides aviation services to the US market (and is exposed to the economic but not the industrial cycle) as attractive. BBA shares lost some ground on the news of the departure next year of the group's respected chief executive Roberto Quarta but the underlying business is performing strongly. In the latter category Hewett singles out Enodis, which on a consensus forecast of GBP 101m in profits for the current year trades on a miserly forward PE multiple of 5.5.

With a large number of companies in the sector languishing on single-digit PE multiples takeover speculation is rife. The share price of West Midlands- based engineer IMI, for example, has recently climbed on speculation that a private equity buyer is planning a break-up bid. Elsewhere Glasgow-based pumps maker Weir, which fought off a 300p a share takeover offer from Texas- based rival Flowserve, now trades at only 191p and rumours of further moves for the company abound. building materials/merchants

Building materials stocks looked to be staging a recovery from recent lows until everything went wrong in August. Since then, fears about the state of the US market and rising raw material prices have sent shares plummeting. The construction and building materials sector has underperformed the rest of the FTSE 350 by 15 per cent over the last year.

The concern about the US is that, after a number of decent years, the market has peaked and the economy is set for a general slowdown. But the view isn't universal. "It may have peaked in certain respects such as new houses, but it's not coming off the edge of a cliff," says Simon Brown, construction analyst at Williams de Broe. Many of the companies, especially Aggregate Industries, RMC and Hanson, have large exposure to the US and would be hit badly by a slowdown. Plasterboard manufacturer BPB demonstrated the market's fears by coming out with a profits warning in September because of overcapacity in the US plasterboard market.

Consolidation still dominates the sector gossip. After Hanson bought Pioneer and RMC bought Rugby last year, talk is rife of who might be next. Aggregate Industries is often tipped as the next target as observers believe it to be too small to survive on its own. Hepworth has GBP 100m cash and is looking for a European boiler acquisition, and Pilkington has been out buying up Ford's US glass interests.

But the biggest M&A story of the year was Lafarge's unsuccessful GBP 3.4bn takeover bid for Blue Circle. The UK cement producer managed to fight off the French challenge through a mixture of improvements in the Asian operations, cost cutting and share buy-backs. Lafarge still controls a 30 per cent stake and may come back for a second bite next year. sector snapshots - steel

Corus, created from the merger of British Steel and the Dutch group Hoogovens last year, has struggled since the company's shares hit a peak of 174p earlier this year on anticipation of GBP 200m in cost savings flowing from the merger. The enduring strength of sterling has decimated earnings from UK operations and the shares are now near a five-year low of 50p. Corus may have some value as a short-term trading play, but has little else to recommend it.

Good value (98p, 30 June 2000)

banks

Former banking watchdog, Don Cruickshank, says that the banks are making hundreds of millions of pounds by ripping off their long-suffering retail customers. And a glance at the return on equity for a player like Lloyds TSB - at well over 30 per cent - would seem to bear that out. But times are changing and the banking market is getting tougher.

It's already happened to the mortgage banks; they have spent the past few years watching their margins gradually disappear and only the really low-cost banks - like Northern Rock - can survive as pure mortgage operations. The rest have had to diversify into higher margin operations and some, such as Halifax, still have some work left to do.

Then there's e-banking. Egg started off that craze, and the rest have jumped in, fearful that they can't afford to be left behind. But ask around the City and it's hard to find anyone who thinks the perplexing range of new internet banks, such as Halifax's IF.com or Abbey National's cahoot.com, will actually ever make more than the cost of capital. And with so much competition at once combined with a big development and marketing spend, mega losses are on the cards for now.

The clearing banks are unlikely to escape this more cut-throat world. For years they have sat back and grown fat by funding their loans with cheap money from retail depositors. But now that Halifax plans to offer savings- type rates on current accounts, the likes of Barclays can't just carry on regardless.

Still, it's going to be years before increased competition really bites into these superb money generators. In the meantime, and with a fairly benign economic outlook ahead, the banks should do pretty well and that's likely to be reflected in share prices. asset managers/other financial

Asset management is a volatile business at the best of times, but with the rollercoaster ride offered by tech stocks this year things have been especially hairy. At the beginning of the year a player with a big tech book - such as London Pacific - would have seen its shares soar. But when the technology sector collapsed in the spring these companies would have at least partially followed that sector down.

Still, for those with the right nose for an investment, along with a reasonably diversified book, there are good returns to be made. And for players that also have brokerage operations, such as ED&F Man, the future looks bright indeed. An increasing number of people want to buy and sell their own shares rather than just trust their money to fund managers. And the growing levels of dealing activity that result from this should mean pretty decent profits for brokerages. The internet too should help boost this trend so watch out for those with a decent web offering.

The consumer finance companies look in good shape too. A player such as Cattles makes money by lending to those borrowers that the banks turn away. That might sound like a recipe for disaster, but the highly individual approach keeps defaults to a minimum. And the high interest rates charged mean decent profits.

But it's the growth prospects that should keep investors interested. The demand for this service is huge and most players are constrained only by their ability to put in place systems to manage the risk. And Provident Financial is even rolling out the doorstep lending concept into the under- banked eastern European countries. The growth profile alone makes it hard for these companies to go too far wrong. sector snapshots - household products

Reckitt Benckiser's chief executive, Bart Becht, seems to have won round the City. Even among analysts who recommend selling Reckitt's shares there is a recognition that Mr Becht has managed to put some zing into the marketing. Returns, in terms of brand awareness and sales, are now beginning to show through. Reckitt's shares have risen 54 per cent this year. Since it accounts for the lion's share of the sector, Reckitt's success explains why the sector has outperformed all others in 2000. However, as much as one quarter of all its products are oil-derived. The strength of crude and Reckitt;s limited ability to pass on higher costs to its supermarket customers suggest tougher times may lie ahead.

Good value (832p, 8 September 2000)

life assurance

The UK's life market still looks robust. The pension hungry general public is waking up to the fact that the state is no longer the place to look for help in their old age, and that's meant a brisk trade for the life players. Today's relatively low interest rate world has also left life products looking like a better deal than putting cash in the bank. In fact, it's the life market where most of the big composites players are looking to avoid the still tough world of general insurance.

And it's the likes of Legal & General, with its legendary low-cost culture, and the newly created CGNU, with its well-positioned international focus, that should be set for a bright future. Moreover, for those able to make it pay there should be plenty of opportunities to take advantage of the new stakeholder pension.

In fact the market outlook for life products remains a tad better here than it does across the channel in continental Europe. Governments there have been generally slower to bite the bullet on pension reform and that's meant a lot of consolidation rumours buzzing around the City involving the big European players such as Germany's Allianz or Holland's Aegon. But expectations that the big Europeans would steam in have failed to materialise. The thing is that they need scale and the only affordable deals are too small to really satisfy their needs. The demutualising players also look on the small side and the mutual culture might not look so attractive to the continentals.

But not everyone is convinced about the life assurance success story. Royal & Sun Alliance has deliberately focused on general insurance because it believes that the returns available from a recovering general insurance market will soon beat what can be achieved from the increasingly crowded life market. That might be true, but it's a scenario that still looks a long way off. insurance

The insurance market has been pretty tough. But after several years of plummeting premium rates the worst appears to be over, although the recovery still looks decidedly patchy. Motor rates are bounding along with increases of up to 30 per cent but take a sector like marine and things still look flat. And premium rates in property and casualty, while decent enough, still can't match the buoyancy of the motor sector.

Despite better news, several problems still face the insurers. To begin with, and despite the huge losses from storm and earthquake ridden 1999, there's still oodles of excess capital to be soaked up in the global insurance market. And until more of that cash pile has been consumed the world's general players will struggle to pass on really meaty rate increases.

Reinsurance holds the key. Reinsurance rates are going up, but they will have to go up faster than they currently are before the direct players feel sufficiently pinched to start really pushing premium rates up. There could be another 12 months to go before that scenario is working. In the meantime, the patchiness of the recovery means that some sectors could peak before the rest of the market recovery gets fully underway. Again, take motor; the chunky rate increases there have been running for well over a year and that sector must start running out of steam soon.

As for investors they have two basic choices when buying into the insurance recovery: bargain deals or expensive quality.

Take Royal & Sun Alliance; its determination to stick to its core property and casualty business when others wanted life exposure has driven the share price down much too far.

Then there's a high quality player like Independent Insurance; even when the market was rock-bottom it never made underwriting losses and does not need to waste the recovery turning round a loss-making book.

The trouble is that this kind of quality is far from cheap. electricity

After getting hammered early in the year, electricity shares are back in vogue as investors come to recognise the real growth that can come from these boring utilities.

Much of the growth is driven by international expansion. Scottish Power, National Grid and Powergen have all made big US acquisitions.

All should be able to use their sharp cost-cutting skills to deliver a good return on their investments. International Power, the overseas part of recently demerged National Power, is also looking stateside for growth.

However, it is expecting to build power stations rather than operate entire utilities.

But there's also growth to be had at home. The liberalised domestic electricity and gas markets have given imaginative electricity companies room to grow by adding additional retail customers to their books, cross-selling a range of products to them and milking them for cash.

But though the domestic energy markets offer big opportunities, there are also potential pitfalls. Independent Energy, one of the most successful new entrants, collapsed earlier this year as faulty customer information led to billing and ultimately cash-flow problems. Those left in the sector will now be taking extra care.

There's also a race on to hit critical mass.

Analysts think companies need 4-5m customers to survive as energy suppliers. Centrica and Scottish & Southern Energy apart, no quoted energy supplier has that amount. This leaves them plenty of work to do.

But perhaps the biggest challenge for the electricity companies will be the introduction of a new electricity trading mechanism. That's turning the cosy wholesale generation market into a cut-throat contract-based system. Analysts at Merrill Lynch suggest that electricity contract prices have already fallen 10-15 per cent and that forward agreements point to a further 10 per cent fall over the next year.

These falling prices have already prompted British Energy to issue a profits warning and cut its dividend. The other generators shouldn't be hit as badly, but the outcome is yet to be seen. property/real estate

The property sector is in rather good shape. The housing market in the south- east might be cooling but taking some of the froth out of the market could prove to be a welcome way of delivering longer-term stability. The commercial market looks strong too with most sectors turning in decent valuation growth and rental uplifts that at least keep pace with inflation. But take a look at property company share prices and one could be forgiven for thinking that the market is in the depths of recession. Even the sector's giants, such as Land Securities and British Land, are suffering with share prices that languish up to 40 per cent below their NAVs.

Property analysts say that they have never seen property company valuations treated so churlishly against the background of such decent market conditions. It's a situation that's taking its toll on the listed players.

The yawning chasms which separate share prices and NAVs have led many property players to go private; the biggest being the once great MEPC. While others have decided that the best way to realise shareholder value is to simply sell the properties and liquidate the company. And the City thinks that property looks set to remain out of favour with investors for a while yet.

Ironically, that's an opportunity. Every privatisation has involved cash offers that are well below a company's most recent NAV. But the cash on offer has also been much better than the share price. And with some property analysts speculating that another 20 listed players could go private over the next 18 months, there could be more cash offers on the way. The trick is to spot those that are most likely to throw in the towel. transport

The transport sector, as part of the old economy, was out of favour for the early part of the year. It recovered only to be hit by worries over escalating fuel prices.

Most high profile among the companies on the sick list is British Airways. Though it's reasonably well hedged, analysts have still downgraded forecasts as the oil price has refused to budge. But others have been hit too. P&O warned in its final set of results that fuel prices were having a negative impact on its cruise business.

But fuel prices aren't providing the only excitement in the sector. High on the list is rail refranchising. The rail contracts originally decided five years ago are being reorganised and renegotiated. The first one has already been awarded and seven more will be decided over the coming months.

Rail has been one of the fastest growing forms of passenger transport in the UK. So for the winners in refranchising, the prize (and impact on the share price) could be very large. Consolidation is expected on the railways and the big players, anxious to build their market share, could be willing to pay big money for those successful in rail franchising.

Also important for the big public transport operators is a strong performance from their US businesses. Firstgroup, National Express and Stagecoach all made big US acquisitions last year. Stagecoach's acquisition, Coach USA, ran into problems and that led to a collapse in the share price early this year.

Stagecoach now seems to be resolving its US difficulties. National Express and Firstgroup have been more fortunate and their subsidiaries are progressing well. However, Stagecoach's problems have made the markets jittery and a slip could lead to a derating.

The ports sector sprang into life earlier this year after a seemingly complete loss of shareholder interest. It came as they languished on low ratings and financial buyers, attracted by ports' strong cash flows, attempted to take advantage of this.

None were taken over, but the sector was rerated and venture capitalists now seem to have lost interest. However, there are still good buys, particularly as some have exciting property interests not reflected in their share prices.

But much of the interest over the next year is likely to be focused on British Airways. Rod Eddington's first few months in his job as chief executive of BA were hijacked somewhat by merger talks with KLM. Now that has fallen through, he will be able to turn to his main job of returning the business to profitability.

The prospects look good and BA already has a cost-cutting strategy in place. So long as the fuel price doesn't jump even further, that should mean BA returns to profitability next year. mining

The rally in base metals prices has been a restrained one this year, and the share prices of major mining groups have not, in general, been able to repeat their outperformance of the previous year.

Instead, consolidation has been the big theme. Billiton has taken the lead in this field. It bid C$ 1.7bn for Canadian natural resources group Rio Algom, a price that some thought was too high, and followed that with a deal to take up Alcoa's stake in the Worsley alumina refinery in Australia. The deals forced Billiton to raise fresh funds, but they give it a quick leg-up into the copper market. Cash is burning a hole in the pockets of Anglo American as it continues to shed its conglomerate baggage. After the acquisition of Tarmac, Anglo tried to break into the iron ore market by bidding for Australia's North Ltd, but was pipped at the post by Rio Tinto. Eyebrows were raised when new chief executive Tony Trahar hinted the cross-holding with De Beers might be unwound, but others believe the Oppenheimers have no intention of loosening their hold.

Anglo's results comfortably beat forecasts, driven by earnings from its platinum operations. Platinum also boosted Lonmin, whose shares hit a high of 919p in September, a year after we tipped them at almost half that level. But the company's opportunistic bid for the rest of troubled gold miner Ashanti was blocked.

Rio Tinto had a subdued year. The acquisition of North went down well enough, but its copper business had a disappointing 12 months. Rio's return on capital remains the best in the sector, but with Billiton and Anglo attracting more attention, the company will need to work hard to preserve its pre-eminence. support services

The trend for outsourcing continues and support services remains a growth sector. Over the past year, the sector has outperformed the All-Share index by 13 per cent and this strong growth is likely to continue.

The emphasis is gradually changing though. The UK market is maturing, making the high growth levels of the past difficult to repeat. As a result, foreign expansion is taking on an added importance. Continental Europe in particular is some way behind the UK and North America in the outsourcing stakes and the opportunities for expansion there are large.

Foreign markets can often also offer better returns. Harvey Nash recently indicated that its expansion will focus on Europe and Australasia where margins are higher and it can compete on service rather than price.

Geography aside, there's also a shift in work emphasis with white-collar outsourcing gaining in importance. Blue-collar outsourcing tends to be more established and consequently offers lower growth prospects. However, business process outsourcing, which can encompass administration, call centres and IT management is growing rapidly. The market for this white-collar type work is growing at around 20 per cent annually.

Amey has recognised this and is moving away from its construction roots and towards white-collar work. Last year, it acquired Comax which is involved in business process outsourcing and that has increased its presence in the sector massively, leaving it poised for rapid growth.

But blue-collar outsourcing still has some life left. It looks set to get a kick from increased government spending on new schools and hospitals and upgraded roads and railways. That will help contractors like Jarvis that have a close involvement with transport infrastructure projects and others that have an expertise in private finance initiative projects and facilities management like Tilbury Douglas. telecoms

Owning telecom shares over the last year has been like riding a rollercoaster: a rapid ride full of unexpected peaks and troughs, finally arriving back where you started feeling slightly sick. Shares soared at the start of the year, but over the last six months, the telecoms stocks have underperformed the rest of the FTSE 350 by 28 per cent.

So where has it all gone wrong? The networks are in place, and rapid growth is expected for all over the next five years. But investors have started to panic. The business plans are untried, and there's a lot of competition, especially in the small and medium-sized business sector (SME) where BT, Colt, Energis, Atlantic, Thus, Kingston and a host of smaller players are fighting for market share.

There are also concerns about the so-called unbundling of the local loop, the process by which BT has to allow alternative operators access to its local exchanges. This in turn will allow operators to start offering high-speed, high-bandwidth services using ADSL technology. The process should be complete by mid-2001 but things aren't progressing smoothly. New entrants like Energis are complaining that BT is obstructing progress by preventing access to the most popular stations and investors are worried that this is threatening future profitability.

Life is no easier in the mobile sector. Vodafone is the only pure mobile play, and along with BT it has been caught up in the auction process for third generation licences in Europe which are costing billions of pounds. While the potential returns are huge, the technology, let alone the business plan, is still unproved. What's more, a group of mobile operators including Orange is about to come to market and Vodafone shares will be among the first to suffer from the new supply of mobile telecoms paper. leisure/hotels

This year will certainly be one to forget for most leisure companies and no more so than in the travel sector. Beleaguered shareholders in tour operator Thomson Travel eventually succumbed to a GBP 1.7bn bid from Europe's largest operator, Preussag in the summer. There was, however, little to smile about for the band of half a million small shareholders who paid 170p a share when the group floated in 1998. After a bidding war with German rival C&N Touristic, the final take-out price only matched the flotation price.

Investors in Airtours must be ruing the day 12 months ago when the European Competition Commission blocked its bid for First Choice Holidays. Things just went from bad to worse as the company unleashed a series of profits warnings. The aggressive expansion into the German package market proved disastrous with losses spiralling to GBP 100m in the last year. Now even C&N Touristic is thought unlikely to bid for Airtours, whose shares have plunged 50 per cent in the last year.

Profits warnings also came thick and fast at computer games developer Eidos, best known for Tomb Raider starring Lara Croft. Slippage in the product pipeline, poor trading and delays in the release of Sony's PlayStation 2 had a devastating effect on the share price. With a takeover bid yet to emerge - Eidos has been in discussions with a potential suitor since June - finance director Jeremy Lewis resigned earlier this month.

Mike Smith, chief executive of Rank, certainly faced an uphill struggle when he took over the hot seat a year ago. A strategic review was the number one priority and with the debt mountain well over GBP 1bn, disposals were always likely. The Tom Cobleigh pub chain, Odeon cinemas and most recently the holiday camps have all been sold. The video duplication business Deluxe could be next for the chop, which would just leave Hard Rock Cafe and the gaming division. Shareholders, who have seen GBP 2.5bn wiped off the group's market value since 1995, will be hoping the worst is now over.

At least international hoteliers have something to smile about. Hilton is now reaping the benefits of its massive capital expenditure and estate upgrade programme and first-half figures showed buoyant trading. London turned in a strong performance, a trend confirmed by Thistle Hotels and Millennium & Copthorne. London and international operators aside, life for regional operators is less rosy. Valuations in the sector are set to remain low given low growth expectations in the economy, the fact that the cycle has peaked and the zero-sum game in the market. electronics & electricals

Electronics has become something of a beleaguered sector over the last 12 months. Often seen as lying on the fringes of the technology boom, the sector has lost some of its highest-profile members including Marconi, which moved to the IT hardware sector, and Racal, which was bought by Thomson CSF of France. What's left is a bit of a hotchpotch: companies involved in consumer electronics, companies making manufacturing components and companies with exposure to high-tech growth areas.

In the consumer field, NXT and Pace Micro Technology are both aiming to become household names in the next 10 years. NXT is developing flat loudspeakers which enhance performance and is hoping to become as famous as Dolby by licensing out its technology to the likes of DaimlerChrysler and Bang & Olufsen. Pace makes set-top boxes for digital TV but is hoping that the boxes will eventually become gateways for all information into the home.

On the industrial and commercial front, applications are similarly varied. Fairey's products improve manufacturing efficiency, while First Technology makes crash test dummies for car manufacturers and Chloride makes systems that protect power supplies. Controls group Invensys has made a splash since it was created in the merger of BTR and Siebe. With the market already jittery about the acquisition of troubled Dutch software group Baan the company released its first profits warning in mid-September, sending the shares crashing.

While lacking the glamour of the IT and telecoms sectors, the electronics sector also lacks the volatility. The shares rose and fell in the tech boom, but the movements were not as exaggerated as elsewhere. Companies in the sector can offer excellent prospects for investors, but the nature of the business means that comparisons are difficult to find, making the investment decision that little bit harder. breweries, beverages, pubs, restaurants

The long awaited consolidation in the European brewing sector finally happened this year with the leading international brewers vying for some prize assets. The country's largest brewer, Scottish & Newcastle, with a 29 per cent market share, was first off the mark, bidding GBP 1.7bn for the brewing interests of French group Danone. The price paid can only be described as full, but S&N was eager to gain control of the premium Kronenbourg lager brand which it had been brewing under license.

Not to be outdone, privately owned Interbrew entered the UK market with vengeance buying both the Whitbread and Bass brewing operations for GBP 2.7bn. Not surprisingly, the regulator was hardly going to sit on the sidelines as the combined operations give Interbrew a 33 per cent share of the domestic market. The Competition Commission is currently investigating the regulatory issues, and though Interbrew may retain its dominant position, it will most likely have to make some concessions to placate the authorities. Interbrew itself is rumoured to be considering an IPO later this year.

Meanwhile, Whitbread, having failed in its bid for Allied Domecq pubs last year, has decided to do away with its own pubs to focus on its leisure businesses. The 3000-strong pub estate is now officially for sale and is expected to fetch around GBP 1.5bn.

Not to be left out of proceedings the largest regional brewer, Wolverhampton & Dudley, shocked the market in May, reporting profits well below market expectations. The shares collapsed and it wasn't long before entrepreneur Robert Beare, with the backing of private equity firm Botts & Co, entered the fray. Amid shareholder unrest, Wolves' days as a quoted company seem numbered.

No such problems in the spirits sector, which has been enjoying a resurgence in fortunes in recent years. Allied Domecq and Diageo have both enjoyed strong price and volume growth and now look set to do battle in the coming months when Seagram auctions its drinks business. Diageo has already laid its cards on the table, joining forces with French group Pernod Ricard. While Allied, which has the most to gain, may go it alone.

The other notable corporate activity concerned the Granada and Compass merger. The shares in the hotels to food outsourcing and servicing giant have had a rocky ride lately.

A revenue warning from Granada Media, in which the group retains a 80 per cent stake, certainly hasn't helped. Following a strategic review it now seems likely that some or all of the hotel portfolio, which includes the Posthouse, Heritage and Le Meridien brands, could be sold off. Food producers is one of those sectors that bounce back into fashion every time investors take flight from tech stocks. But although the volatility of the last couple of weeks has propped up shares, this temporary rise cannot compensate for the fact that the sector has underperformed the FTSE All-Share by 13.5 per cent in the last 12 months.

Nevertheless, there have been some interesting developments in the sector. The biggest, perhaps, was Unilever's acquisition of the US-based Best Foods last June for a hefty GBP 12.3bn. The acquisition, deemed to be expensive by the City, is supposed to help Unilever to speed up its own sluggish growth. It probably will - Best Foods is one of the best operators among the global food processors, but Unilever is now facing a daunting task of restructuring and integrating its acquisitions at the same time.

Meanwhile, Cadbury Schweppes, has been shopping too.

Everyone wanted Cadbury to buy something sweet, but with few confectionery offers on the market, Cadbury decided to pay $ 1.45bn for the US-based Snapple Beverage to strengthen its US drinks business. Snapple is currently the leader in the US juice drink market, where its combined share with Cadbury will now stand at a solid 25 per cent. The good news is Cadbury still has enough cash for a sweets deal.

Elsewhere, Unigate's Malton food division has been suffering because of higher UK pig prices. Malton's profits are expected to be down by GBP 5m at the interim stage - that is, if it still belongs to Unigate by then: the company previously hinted that it might sell Malton, estimated to be worth about GBP 50m. Plus, Unigate itself is rumoured to be a takeover target, although the group is also said to be considering an offer for the UK-based Hazlewood Foods. food & drug retailers

UK supermarkets are not ripping their customers off and there is enough competition in the sector - this is official. If it makes you relieved as a consumer, imagine the relief of the supermarkets when it became clear that the Competition Commission would not demand any divestment from the big five.

Even though the review was out only two weeks ago, the Competition Commission let its position be known well in advance, thus allowing the supermarket shares to shrug off the weight of uncertainty.

This is not to say that the sector has since shot up - food retailers are anything but a high-growth area. But there appears to be some improvement among those which six months ago looked less than promising.

Sainsbury, although still far from recovered from the wounds inflicted by Asda's price offensive, is looking healthier. Sales are improving, stores are getting modernised and IT overhaul has been entrusted to an experienced outsider, Andersen Consulting. Improving efficiency is still a priority, but the high cost of the restructuring should be paid for out of the proceeds from the sale of Homebase, which seems to have attracted a few bidders.

Safeway, which only a year ago was looking pretty dismal, seems to have got its act together.

The new-ish ex-Wal-Mart CEO Carlos Criado-Perez responded to Wal-Mart with its very own weapon - by cutting prices, with a resulting increase in sales and an extra million customers a week flocking to the stores. It remains to be seen whether with all the promotions and new customers Safeway will be able to keep its profit margins.

But then Safeway's shares have been lifted by more than just its own brighter prospects - it is still considered to be the sector's favourite takeover target, and the City has been busy speculating about potential bidders.

Meanwhile, Tesco, the reigning king of the sector, is above all the skirmishes. Having conquered Britain, it is now focusing on international expansion, and the two biggest foreign operations, Hungary and Thailand, are expected to deliver profits this year. retailers

Polarisation, deflation, competition - these are the three words that best summarise what has been happening in the retail sector in the last year.

The closer a retailer is to the extreme within its sector, the better it seems to be doing - just look at the darling of fashionistas, Selfridges, or the king of discounters, Matalan.

Meanwhile, mid-market, with the exception of Next, remains synonymous with desperation, epitomised by Marks & Spencer. Despite a number of radical steps - price cuts, management overhaul and the introduction of a designer collection to name just a few - M&S has so far been unable to stop its freefall.

Price deflation is not helping - an increasingly choosy and spoilt-for-choice customer is not willing to part with his or her cash as easily as some years ago. Against the background of rising costs - fuel and import being the main offenders - consumer prices in the UK continue to fall and the pressure on margins, especially in the commoditised clothing sector, is increasing.

True, despite general doom and gloom, there are some potentially interesting developments in the sector. Kingfisher, which has finally decided to demerge its less-than-exciting general merchandise division, is going to enjoy the higher rating of its successful DIY business, B&Q. Dixons' European expansion should start paying off and game consols sales should bounce back after the release of the new platforms, although getting rid of Freeserve seems to be a prerequisite of the full recovery.

But these bits of good news are drops in the ocean.

The reality is that general retailers continue to remain very much out-of- fashion, and for a good reason. Polarisation, deflation and competition will continue to dominate the retail horizon. With consumers being presented with new opportunities to spend cash almost daily, the battle for hearts and wallets is poised to intensify. Expect more casualties. broadcasting & media agencies

The arrival of digital broadcasting is shaking up the sector and providing new revenue generating opportunities. In the television industry it has greatly increased the number of channels, which is fragmenting audiences, and has brought in interactive services such as shopping and banking.

This shake-up encouraged ITV giants Carlton and United News & Media to announce a merger at the beginning of the year, but regulatory requirements scuppered their plans and allowed Granada Media to steal the show. United eventually sold all of its ITV franchises to Granada leaving Carlton in a poor second place.

A new broadcasting bill, expected within the next couple of years, is anticipated to pave the way for the creation of a single company to control ITV. A single company will be better able to compete with increased competition from new channels. It is widely anticipated that enough homes will have converted to digital in the next 10 years to allow the government to switch off the analogue signal.

The radio industry is also going digital but at a much slower pace. Digital radio sets will deliver better quality sound and the ability to receive text but the high cost of equipment is still holding back sales. But this hasn't stopped radio being the fastest growing advertising medium. It is not just benefiting from dot-coms trying to build their brands but is also seen as a cost-effective option for advertisers looking for a broad reach.

Also in this section are advertising and marketing groups such as WPP, which became the world's largest agency this year when it acquired US group Young & Rubicam.

The industry has been going through a long period of consolidation as advertisers have favoured appointing single agencies for all their global needs. Advertising and marketing groups are dependent on strong global economies for growth and so long as the economy is performing well, so should they. publishing & printing

Ever since US media conglomerate Time Warner and internet service provider America Online announced their plans to merge, the fortunes of the IT and media sectors have been tied together.

The idea is that large media companies will attract internet traffic and prosper because they have valuable content and well-known brands. Publishers such as Reed, Reuters and Pearson have all announced plans to invest vast sums of money distributing their products over the internet. But while these announcements initially guaranteed hikes in the companies' share prices investors are now wondering when these investments will pay off.

For music publishers, though, it has been a different story. The industry has always feared that new technology such as MP3 - which allows music to be downloaded from the internet - would lead to mass pirating of content. It didn't help that industry leaders such as EMI were slow to embrace the opportunities of distributing their music content digitally. EMI has also been plagued by its failed attempts to find a partner ever since Seagram walked away from a deal in April 1998. The collapse of its planned merger with Time Warner's music interests is also likely to weigh heavily on the shares as the eventual likelihood of a deal diminishes.

The value of the FTSE media sector rose quickly with the market euphoria for TMT stocks in the first quarter of the year and despite falling far off its year high it is still only 4 per cent down from the beginning of the year. Despite its strong ties with the technology sector the publishing industry is still very much driven by advertising revenues. So long as the economic outlook remains buoyant, whatever the current thinking on the potential of the internet, publishers should do well. IT hardware

While the IT hardware industry is dominated by US companies such as Cisco Systems, Dell and Compaq, which supply much of the world's personal computers and networking equipment, European companies dominate in the area of telecommunications.

The expected rise in the use of the internet is underpinning growth across the industry and whereas the internet has helped push PC sales in the US, in Europe it is expected to push sales of mobile devices such as mobile phones and hand-held computers. Forrester Research predicts that in three years' time the market for mobile e-commerce will run into trillions of dollars. 3G technology means mobile phones will be able connect to the internet faster and will be able to offer more services such as live video.

Although the UK doesn't have a big mobile phone manufacturer such as Nokia or Ericsson it does have many companies that supply technology to this industry. ARM Holdings, for example, has cornered the world market for mobile phone microchips and is widely tipped to be the next Intel. It is far ahead of competitors in this market - it is estimated that 50-70 per cent of the mobile market uses its designs - and has a good infrastructure in place to attract the biggest original equipment manufacturers. It is also moving into designing chips for other fast-growing sectors such as smart cards, set-top boxes and for bluetooth technology, which links different systems wirelessly.

Fibre-optics components maker Bookham Technology is also a hope for the future. It bucked the trend in the tech sector by floating on the main market in April, when most investors were turning away from tech stocks. Bookham has the technology to manufacture silicon-based fibre-optic components faster and more cheaply than those assembled manually. It is the internet again and the demand for wide bandwidth telecoms applications which is prompting the boom in demand for fibre optics.

The boom in telecommunications and the expected demand for internet on the move is really driving the IT hardware industry. According to a recent report by Merrill Lynch every large cap stock in the European IT hardware sector has had its earnings forecasts upgraded for 2001 and the sector on aggregate has been upgraded by 8 per cent.

Nokia recently reported better-than-expected third-quarter results with mobile phone sales rocketing up 59 per cent to E5.46bn. This followed similarly good figures from US companies such as Microsoft and Sun Microsystems.

Despite the rosy outlook, investors have recently turned sceptical again and the FTSE IT hardware index has lost 28 per cent of its value since early September. Over the past 12 months, however, it has been the best performing sector and seen a 128 per cent increase to 7,066.20. tobacco

Tobacco shares have been a runaway success this year. Tobacco has been the second best-performing FTSE 350 sector in 2000, rising 38 per cent and outperforming the index by 51 per cent.

It doesn't take a rocket scientist to work out why. March's technology rout and the growing jitters over the US economy, interest rates, oil prices and inflation, have seen institutions heading for the safety of so-called defensive stocks.

Negative factors such as US litigation and the prospect of advertising bans are more than outweighed by the tobacco companies' stable earnings profile, high cash generation and juicy dividends. All three companies have been busy cutting costs, pushing through price increases and expanding overseas to boost growth. Improving prospects in emerging markets like eastern Europe and the Far East are also likely to help profits this year.

ABN Amro forecasts BAT will report a 17 per cent rise in normalised pre-tax profit this year to GBP 2.27bn, boosted by the impact of last year's acquisition of Rothmans, and an 8 per cent rise in the dividend to 28.3p. Imperial is expected to show a 10 per cent rise in profits to GBP 448m and a 10 per cent rise in dividend to 30.25p. Gallaher is expected to report a slight fall in profit to GBP 342m because of the timing of changes in duty last year and the impact on interest charges of the GBP 246m acquisition of Russian cigarette maker Liggett-Ducat. But it should increase the dividend by 6 per cent to 23.5p.

Gallaher's acquisition of Liggett-Ducat is part of the consolidation process underway in the industry. BAT bought Rothmans last year and Imperial has been on the acquisition trail. Although M&A activity has waned recently, some analysts expect it to pick up next year. Gallaher, the smaller of the three tobacco stocks, is seen as a prime takeover candidate, with BAT seen as one of the likely bidders. IT software/computer services

After high-tech hype rocketed stocks to stratospheric heights, reality finally bit the IT software sector earlier this year. The bursting of the tech bubble in April and recent jitters over earnings in the US have contributed to the sector losing around 30 per cent of its value since the start of the year, making it the third worst performer of the FTSE 350 in 2000. Since April, the sector is down 54 per cent, under-performing the FTSE 350 by 51 per cent.

The damage is unlikely to be fatal, however, and indeed many stocks, particularly those new technology stocks with focus on e-commerce and the internet, have retained their stellar ratings. Surfcontrol and Staffware have both made huge gains on the stock market this year through their exposure to web-based activities, even though their revenues at this early stage remain tiny compared to those of older technology stocks such as Computacenter and Sage.

Computacenter was one the worst performing software stocks this year, with shares losing around two-thirds of their value since January and ongoing concerns over declining margins are unlikely to help its near-term prospects.

Acquisitions have helped accounting and payroll software supplier Sage maintain its consistently strong performance and the prospects for selling new software and servicing its existing customers remain excellent. Nonetheless, Sage has suffered badly on the markets - shares are down by nearly 40 per cent since the start of the year.

Independent software and computer services analyst Richard Holway believes the collapse in the share prices of companies like Sage is "ludicrous." "Future success in the sector will be built on growth in recurring revenues," he said, "rather than over-optimistic forecasts of future earnings". Over 70 per cent of Sage's current revenues are recurring.

The shift in sentiment towards e-commerce and internet-based stocks is only likely to be temporary and while there will always be "flavours of the month" like Staffware, Mr Holway believes that the backbone of the industry will continue to be represented by those with a solid revenue base like Sage.

Exposure to mobile telecoms, meanwhile, has helped three of the sector's other established players, Logica, CMG and Sema, to consolidate their high market valuations and largely avoid the big sell-off. Logica's revenues are now 40 per cent-based on mobile networks, while CMG saw its interim operating profits in telecoms rise eight-fold last year.

Sema, now the world's largest supplier of mobile communications software, did not post quite such impressive growth as CMG but remains well-positioned in a market from which most analysts still expect sky-high growth, despite the disappointing take-up of WAP so far.

According to Mr Holway's most recent estimates, based on historic PE ratio averages, the IT sector faces a further 20-25 per cent slide in the fourth quarter, before a recovery can begin midway through next year. Of course, that won't stop the market taking a few punts on companies such as Staffware or Telework in the meantime. sector snapshots - internet and insurance brokers

- Investors are now looking at the internet with a more realistic eye. At the height of the frenzy for internet stocks Freeserve was worth over GBP 9bn, but recently fell out of the FTSE100 with a valuation of just GBP 1.7bn. Internet hotel company Telecity floated after the shakeout, but has recently seen investors question its prospects. The shares reached 2,307p in September but are now trading below the 775p issue price at 662p. Freeserve: Good value (337p, 30 June 2000) Telecity: High enough (1,520p, 4 Aug 2000)

- Claims Direct specialises in personal injury claims and acts as an intermediary between claimants and lawyers. The thing is that Claims Direct has been turning in a heady pace of growth for years and now that legal aid has been scrapped for personal injury cases that trend looks set for a further boost. The shares have risen to over 240p since floating at 180p in July.

No previous IC coverage

- Not that long ago the insurance brokers were busily consolidating, but with all the big deals now done Jardine Lloyd Thompson thinks that it's probably set to stay independent. But deal or no deal, business has been good for this company. Brokerage profits continue to roll in and with a decent outlook for energy, property and reinsurance rates, Jardine should have some good times ahead.

Fairly priced (322p, 4 August 2000)

aerospace/defence

The aerospace and defence sector has recently rallied strongly - outperforming the FTSE 350 by 23.9 per cent since March. The weakening of sterling against the dollar, strong defence spending in the US, and the high oil price - which could boost orders from the Middle East - are all cited as factors justifying higher ratings.

The most attractive companies have either a strong high-tech presence and/or have developed a business model which includes a major servicing element. Alex Hunter of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter identifies BAE Systems and Rolls- Royce in these categories. "BAE has a strong order book, a high quality of management and is trading on an unusually low rating," says Mr Hunter. BAE's commercial aerospace division is performing strongly, producing first-half profits of GBP 34m (compared to break-even in the first half of 1999) and looks set to make further progress in the second half as Airbus continues to win orders for large commercial jets. Airbus's planned super jumbo project, the A3XX looks likely to go ahead and will provide a further avenue for growth.

Despite seeing its shares slump to 161p in September after a GBP 120m provision was made to meet the cost of new emission regulations on turbines the long- term prospects of Rolls-Royce also appear good. "Rolls-Royce has a huge earnings potential from servicing engines while its strategy of leveraging its gas turbine technology by expanding out of aerospace into power generation looks like a sound one," says Mr Hunter. Like BAE, Rolls-Royce also stands to benefit from the development of the A3XX.

The jet engine maker has already secured a deal with Singapore airlines to power the 25 A3XX's the carrier has on order. A number of companies remain acquisitive and the long-term trend is towards consolidation. Cobham exemplifies this. The aerospace group gained a foothold in south-east Asia this April with the purchase of Australia's National Jet Services for GBP 23.7m. sector snapshots - automobiles

- Torotrak's development is progressing well and its ground-breaking transmission system should arrive by 2003-04. Management's efforts are now focused on signing agreements with major motor manufacturers. Though the target utility vehicles market is currently slumping in the US, that shouldn't affect Torotrak's long-term prospects as an upswing is anticipated before the product launch. Good value (415p, June 30 2000).

- Although GKN has an automotive business that's exposed to the struggling markets, the company remains confident about the future and thinks it will grow by increasing market share. The diversified nature of GKN means that even if this growth doesn't materialise, growth should come from elsewhere in the company. In particular, the industrial services division is growing rapidly on the back of a rapidly expanding pallet-pooling business. Good value (903p, 11 August 2000).

chemicals

This year has not been an easy ride for the UK chemicals sector. The strength of the pound, the weakness of the euro, a slowdown in demand and the highest oil prices for a decade have squeezed profit margins and frightened off investors by the truckload. On the back of depressed share prices, most companies have consolidated and refocused but the stocks remain broadly out of favour.

Both ICI and polymer producer British Vita have suffered in tough market conditions. Although there are signs that ICI's transformation from bulk to specialty chemicals producer is beginning to bring its rewards, debt remains a major problem and further disposals are needed before shares mount a sustained recovery.

Raw materials costs, meanwhile, are likely to maintain pressure on Vita's margins for the near term, although its fundamentals remain robust. While chemical companies have suffered more than most as a result of the tech stocks boom, exposure to technology has helped Johnson Matthey to stand out from the crowd. Interest in its cutting-edge fuel cell technology and a healthy cash position have helped its share price soar by nearly 80 per cent since late last year, bucking the sector's downward trend.

With the failed Air Products and Air Liquide bids behind it, BOC is making the best of life as an independent in a consolidated industrial gases market. Third-quarter results showed an increase in pre-tax profits on last year and an improved cash flow. It may not be too long before bid speculation casts its shadow once more.

Laporte took the most extreme step in its own restructuring process in September when it hived off over half the company to focus on specialty organics. Cutting capital expenditure increases its growth potential, while a slimmed-down Laporte may prove irresistible for a hungry European predator.
