urn:contentItem:5TKM-YKV1-DY19-C451-00000-00Full responses: Media Monday chief executive survey2018-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:43ZLexisNexisFull responses: Media Monday chief executive surveyJennifer Duke

Read the full Q and A with Australia's top media executives.

Fairfax Media asked 14 chief executives and company leaders from across the media sector for their thoughts on disruption, regulation and where the opportunities are for their businesses. The full answers are presented below.

Participants were: Tim Worner, Seven West Media; Hugh Marks, Nine Entertainment Co; Paul Anderson, Network Ten; Michael Miller, News Corp; Greg Hywood, Fairfax Media: Patrick Delany, Foxtel; Mike Sneesby, Stan; Grant Blackley, Southern Cross Austereo; Cathy O'Connor, Nova Entertainment; Graham Burke, Village Roadshow; Scott Lorson, FetchTV; Paul Dykzeul, Bauer Media Group; Ciaran Davis, Here There & Everywhere (Australian Radio Network); and Andy Penn, Telstra.

Media is going through radical disruption with the rise of tech players like Netflix, social media platforms, digital classifieds and online video. What do you consider to be the biggest threats and the biggest opportunities for your business?

Andy Penn, Telstra:

We have seen unparalleled growth in video streaming which shows no sign of slowing. The availability of content anytime, anywhere across a growing number of international and local platforms is a clear benefit for our customers. It is also driving massive demand on our network so the investments we are making -including to lead the market in 5G - is hugely important, and makes us excited to be in the business of connectivity at this time of rapid change. Our goal is to bring customers closer to their passions by delivering the best network, and creating simple and compelling media experiences with our products like Telstra TV and the AFL, NRL, MyFootball, and Netball Live apps. Customers are looking for value, but not at the expense of the customer experience. Our opportunity is to partner with all our customers favourite platforms to bring all that content together, giving them choice, flexibility and a seamless customer experience that truly blends from home to mobile and back again.

Tim Worner, Seven West Media:

I'd argue the biggest threat is complacency. The competition for eyeballs and engagement, and the advertising dollars that follow, is intensifying every day. Our marketplace continues to change rapidly and a failure to match the speed of that change inside our company is a threat, no question. But, we have a strong stable of brands, world-class live news, live sport all year round and content that resonates around the world. The opportunity we have is that in this fragmenting world, the value of mass reach will only increase, as will providing advertisers a brand-safe environment and the most rigorous and transparently audited metrics in the market. The exponential demand for content is massive opportunity for Seven Studios. The only way these over the top services can succeed is by having the best fresh content, and they will chew through it at a great rate. We're Australia's biggest producer of high-quality long-form content, and we're already selling to Netflix, to broadcasters in the UK, cable networks in the US and many others around the world. What's also very handy for us is that the battle for eyeballs is now firmly centred around connected TVs, not mobile. And the big digital players have nowhere near as strong a foothold on the big screen as they do on the little screen.

Hugh Marks, Nine Entertainment Co:

I'll start with the opportunity. Has always been and will remain our ability to engage with audiences around quality content. It's what Nine does. And when the biggest threat is the competition from new distribution platforms, we've set ourselves the goal to benefit from the content we own and control to make more from those new distribution platforms. We've done that through 9Now, Stan and our growing digital publishing platforms. From an advertising industry perspective, being able to unlock the benefit of greater distribution of our content , and thereby provide great opportunities for advertisers, is the key to success.

Paul Anderson, Network Ten:

Digital disruption has brought its challenges but the great thing is that demand for engaging video and audio content is insatiable. We are a premium video content brand, that's our bread and butter, so we are embracing change and are very well placed to grow our business in this ever connected, video obsessed world. Ten has always been different - we are the network for the young and young at heart - and because of that our viewers "lean in" to our content. You only have to see how Twitter lights up during The Bachelor or Australian Survivor to see that in action and that's without being able to track the group chats happening on Snapchat, WhatsApp and other platforms. We believe that by producing excellent broadcast quality content that entertains and connects with our audience, they will watch it and engage with it. We can monetise this so we are excited about our future. The opportunity for us is to better connect our content with our viewers, the cord cutters and the cord-nevers, by investing in our platform ecosystem. This means better understanding how audiences want content and giving them, and our advertisers, more of what they want. Our focus is to provide amazing content to our audiences wherever they want it.

Michael Miller, News Corp:

Undoubtedly the biggest challenge to all media businesses is the rise of the digital platforms and their impact on the distribution of local content, digital advertising revenues, and consumption of quality journalism. The digital platforms use our unique content to attract and keep users within their ecosystem, yet we are not remunerated for their use of our content. They also intermediate the relationship with our readers and set unreasonable terms on how we can engage with them. The biggest opportunity for News Corp is in being the provider of original, local journalism, with local voices for local audiences. Trust in journalism and ???traditional' mastheads has increased against a backdrop of digital disinformation. The provision of local content and the roles of journalists and editors are important to communities across Australia. The combined Foxtel/FOX SPORTS also presents huge opportunities for News Corp. We have an ambitious strategy to deliver Foxtel's quality sports, news and entertainment content to many more Australians, and have a team of world-class executives to do this.

Greg Hywood, Fairfax Media:

The greatest opportunity for us was delivered through the media law reform which enabled the proposed merger with Nine. Once completed, the logic of the deal - strongly growing digital-based earnings across the diversified businesses - will likely generate a market re-rate.

Patrick Delany, Foxtel:

The threats and opportunities we face are different sides of the same coin. The biggest threat is the way traditional media has been disrupted by new companies offering content directly to consumers online. Our biggest opportunity is that we have an unbeatable suite of extraordinary content to take on the digital disrupters and we also have the ability to own family viewing in front of the most important screen of all, which is the big TV in every Australian home.

Mike Sneesby, Stan:

Even though consumers have quickly taken to streaming TV in the last few years, the shift to internet delivered television is still at a relatively early stage. Stan has become a key part of that evolution in the Australian television landscape and our long-term opportunities come from continuing to lead that evolution from a local Australian perspective.

Grant Blackley, Southern Cross Austereo:

Netflix is healthy competition to our television business. Our challenge is to continue working with our television partners to deliver great programming for viewers while providing reliable local news, information and, of course, a trusted and free service. That's our point of difference and our advantage. Spotify and other music streaming services have unquestionably disrupted the audio industry. However, we see this as an opportunity, not only to continue delivering great music, but to constantly improve our local and national shows. Radio remains the place where audiences go to discover new music and to hear about their local community. We have a finger on the local pulse of communities throughout all of Australia and importantly the ability to engage consumers in the real world, which is incredibly unique. People are always going to want to be entertained and we are excited to have new formats that allow us to make audio even more personal. The audio landscape is incredibly fertile right now and Southern Cross' expertise in this space gives us great confidence in our ability to benefit from emerging technology.

Cathy O'Connor, Nova Entertainment:

Digital platforms enhance established media such as radio and provide more opportunities for strong brands such as Nova and smooth to diversify their audiences. We have also leveraged our capability in content creation into new digital products such as our mobile platform targeting Millennials, known as GOAT. The increasing connectivity in cars and homes and advancements in voice activation technology provide an opportunity for us to reimagine the customer experience of radio and create more value through new forms of digital interaction with listeners. This requires a delicate balance between continued investment in our very successful core business and making a few bets on the future.

Graham Burke, Village Roadshow:

The biggest effect on our company is the additional competition for eyeballs from Netflix. They are able to produce on a global scale and Australia is just a semicolon. However, it's not all bad as it is contributing to enhancing in people's culture film entertainment as major part for what they do. Then when they go out, more inclined to go to the movies because they like filmed drama and want to experience it in a social environment on a big screen.

Scott Lorson, FetchTV:

Fetch is an aggregation service offering "All your Entertainment in one place". The recent explosion in quality content options, NBN-led improvements in broadband speeds, and strategic move of Telco's into the Entertainment market all serve to validate the Fetch business model and enhance our consumer proposition. We are now swimming downstream with the right product, right partners, and market momentum. Our biggest risk is failing to evolve at a sufficient pace. and conceding our hard earned leadership position a nimble competitor.

Paul Dykzeul, Bauer Media Group:

I doubt very much that we are seeing the end of "radical disruption" - in fact, it's only a matter of time before the disruptors will be disrupted. It's increasingly difficult to see where disruption is coming from and typically, it won't come from an obvious source. The biggest threat, I believe, is the threat of time or in truth, the lack of it. Consuming information and content will become an even bigger challenge particularly for companies that produce engaging content in real time. Every magazine in the world is being produced in a different way compared to five years ago. The market is changing, the world is changing, people's tastes are changing and as a result, our business is changing. As people's consumption habits evolve, our business evolves and this presents great opportunities for us. We are always on the lookout for opportunities to expand the business.

Ciaran Davis, Here There & Everywhere (Australian Radio Network):

Radio is the core of our offering and continues to be as relevant as ever. Its ability to retain and grow audiences during this period of rapid digital disruption is down to its adaptability and understanding of how the consumption of radio is changing. Let's not forget that we're fundamentally a content business with a long history in building audiences and connecting them with our advertising partners. That won't change but we are successfully utilising new technologies to further engage and build audiences by extending our content into digital publishing and social platforms.

Media companies are getting closer to each other, whether that be mergers or sharing production and back-end costs. Are traditional rivalries dead?

Andy Penn, Telstra:

Traditional rivalries are not dead. Legislation in Australia ensures healthy competition will remain. But consumers are demanding value and we need to adapt to their expectations. That means finding the right economics to deliver a great experience, even when costs required to create and deliver content are high. So companies need to look for synergies, and partnerships across the value chain are becoming more common to capitalise on opportunities to be more cost efficient. In fact, the competition in video streaming is actually growing the total audience size and consumption which is benefiting everyone. So those partnerships are likely to continue. We bring a great deal of technology expertise and a large customer base to the partnerships we have the likes of Foxtel, Netflix, Stan, and the biggest sports in Australia.

Tim Worner, Seven West Media:

They are not dead, but it is very different, and that is compared to how it was as recently as, say, two years ago. No question we are now in a world of ???frenemies'. Our mantra is ???collaborate on technology, compete on content'. As we showed with our playout operation joint venture with Nine Entertainment Co, there are opportunities to make savings, and maybe even build growth together. That business just announced Southern Cross as its first outside client. And as much as we have fundamental disagreements with some of the ways the digital giants operate and are allowed to operate, we are clients of theirs, they are customers of ours and we do collaborate from time to time. So again, it's a frenemy relationship.

Hugh Marks, Nine Entertainment Co:

In the modern media landscape the notion of rivals who can't work together is dead. Of course we still compete. It's one of the most competitive markets in the world. But there is also recognition that the world has changed and where there is opportunities to build mutually beneficial relationships where it makes strategic sense we will do so - recent examples of this in Nine's case can be seen both with Your Money, a partnership for a business channel between us and News Corp, or the merger of the Nine and Seven playout centres. As Ken Auletta notes in his recent book in an era digital disruption ???frenemies' are increasingly the way of the future.

Paul Anderson, Network Ten:

Scale has become incredibly important and this might have something to do with the gargantuan size of the FAANGs (Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google) and the eye watering amount of money they can pour into content and technology. Ten is now part of CBS, one of the biggest and most successful mass media companies in the world. We plan to take full advantage of that through leveraging content, technology and monetisation. As to traditional rivalries, yes we are in a very competitive industry but Ten isn't interested in school yard skirmishes with our older rivals, we never have been. Having said that, where it makes sense to collaborate and find better ways to operate and promote our industry then we will always be up for a conversation, frenemy or not.

Michael Miller, News Corp:

The competition for consumers and an increased share of clients' marketing dollars has always been fierce and this ferocity is growing. That competitive spirit will always remain. The old silos that divided and separated print, TV and radio have been replaced by multimedia companies. However, where working together makes business sense, we will do. Recent agreements such as the commercial printing deal with Fairfax will help with scale and efficiency and makes commercial sense. Similarly our joint venture with Nine, the Your Money channel; and the arrangement to broadcast Sky News content on WIN regional television network. And while we will continue to compete, as publishers we are strongly aligned in the message that ???The Truth Builds Trust.' This campaign creatively asserts the importance and value of trusted journalism and authentic storytelling - which lies at the heart of our great news brands - to advertisers. It reminds companies of the importance of associating their brand with articles and in environments their customers trust.

Greg Hywood, Fairfax Media:

Rivalry in the media will never end. We all care too much. The economic stresses the industry has faced has delivered cooperation at the back end, but competition around journalism and content is as hot as ever.

Patrick Delany, Foxtel:

No.

Mike Sneesby, Stan:

Many aspects of the media landscape have evolved as international players have entered the market. This means local players have to adjust their business models, strategies and play to their strengths. Inevitability those adjustments, combined with developments in the regulatory environment, will lead to mergers and acquisitions, partnerships and deals that would have seemed impossible three to five years ago.

Grant Blackley, Southern Cross Austereo:

Traditional media companies aren't competing on distribution channels, they are competing on content and sales, so it makes sense for us consolidate back office functions and save money which can be better used on delivering great content to engage our respective audiences and advertisers. This is particularly important in the face of emerging players and unregulated giants like Facebook, which have such a clear and inequitable competitive advantage. We have long worked with other regional TV broadcasters on transmission facilities. We are now working with Nine and Seven for TV playout. We have joint ventures with other commercial radio broadcasters to transmit digital radio around Australia. As an industry, we are moving together so we can spend more money on content, remain vibrant and entertain audiences in the great way we always have across new and existing delivery mechanisms.

Cathy O'Connor, Nova Entertainment:

I observe most media companies very willing to engage in conversations around operational efficiencies. However, from a strategic point of view, company to company, product to product, competition will remain and to me, we need strive for both. There has always been a bigger win in competitors working together to grow their sector. Industry wide initiatives to better position and promote radio as a sector are now common place with moves into automated holdings and shared streaming apps, to name a few.

Graham Burke, Village Roadshow:

In our space we continue to compete in traditional ways and the people that run our Exhibition and Distribution businesses are vitally interested in market share and traditional rivalries are very much alive. Any further mergers are unlikely given ACCC.

Scott Lorson, FetchTV:

Australian media organisations are experiencing profound structural shifts brought on by technology advancements, international competition and rapidly shifting viewing behaviours. The consumer is now in control and preference is perishable. Focus has shifted from short-term market share wins to industry wide initiatives to "protect the species", as legacy players buy time to re-invent their business models. In this context, all bets are on, enemies are frenemies, and companies must embrace partnerships with traditional and non traditional players to survive and excel. For Fetch, our entire business is built on partnerships, and we consider this orientation to be a core competency and competitive differentiator.

Paul Dykzeul, Bauer Media Group:

I believe that if ever there was a time where media companies should and must work together it is now. All media companies are facing challenges that are materially affecting their business. Digital disruption is challenging all traditional media outlets and as such, a collective approach to the challenges ahead is critical.

Ciaran Davis, Here There & Everywhere (Australian Radio Network):

While efficiencies and synergies drive a lot of the decision making, rivalry and health competition particularly in the ever accelerating news and content cycle will be needed to maintain quality journalism and combat the era/perception of ???Fake News'. Australian radio is one of the most resilient and innovative markets in the world and that's down to strong competition between networks. We all strive for a greater share of audiences and revenue dollars, producing great content and sales innovations, and that's going to intensify.

Facebook and Google are currently at the heart of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's inquiry into how digital platforms impact media. Given how fast disruption and innovation has moved, is there any point for regulators in trying to keep up?

Andy Penn, Telstra:

There is absolutely a need for regulators to keep up in what is a rapidly growing, rapidly changing and incredibly important area. It is fast moving but at the end of the day legislation has to be there to make sure consumers are never disadvantaged.

Tim Worner, Seven West Media:

Yes, there is every point. There is an urgent need to address the market power of these platforms and to create a more level playing field. The global digital giants are massively impacting the market, both commercially and in the effect they have on local news and content production. And they're doing it free from the regulatory burdens imposed on the rest of us. Already the ACCC inquiry has increased awareness of the lack of transparency and spurious reach and viewability claims of some digital platforms. More work needs to be done to ensure media buyers have access to verified and comparable consumer reach information across different mediums. We also hope that the inquiry will result in real action that will have a lasting benefit to Australian news and content production. Traditional media are the ones investing in accurate and trusted news and public affairs, which is so essential for democracy, and we're the ones investing in local production. We have argued that, given the market power of Google and Facebook, a levy or collective licensing regime needs to be developed to ensure professional content producers are being appropriately remunerated for the monetisation of their content by digital platforms.

Hugh Marks, Nine Entertainment Co:

Yes things are constantly changing but there are also themes that have been around for as long as our industry. And working out how new platforms accept responsibility for some of those themes must be a long term agenda. Upholding community standards, negating social harms, upholding accuracy and reliability of information provided to the community are one part. And contribution to our industry and the provision of quality local content to Australians is another. All players must be both held accountable and responsible for what they publish on their platforms and contribute in a meaningful way to our industry and community.

Paul Anderson, Network Ten:

It is ridiculous to say that just because technology evolves at lightning speed or companies are enormous and global that they should be allowed to make their own rules. The ACCC inquiry is very interesting and comes at a really key time. The problems some of these tech giants have with transparency, brand safety, data management, privacy and so on are well known. I sense that the Government and Parliament are willing to act if the ACCC thinks that is the right thing to do.

Michael Miller, News Corp:

While innovation and disruption will continue to transform businesses, anti-competitive conduct requires regulatory attention and News Corp globally continues to detail the various anti-competitive practices of the digital platforms and how these harm content creation. The current ACCC inquiry is world-leading. Regulators around the world, including in the US and Europe, are now also focused on addressing potential anti-competitive conduct of global digital platforms.

Greg Hywood, Fairfax Media:

It's the regulator's job to keep up.

Patrick Delany, Foxtel:

Of course we have to keep up. It is not acceptable that the Wild Wild Web allows our content to be stolen and then monetised by Big Tech. It is not acceptable that fake news and fake advertising enrich organisations that take no responsibility for the harm those things cause. Regulators and society at large are resetting their relationship with big tech and I am confident necessary change is coming, not only in the form of sensible regulation, but from a population weary of data abuses by these platforms.

Mike Sneesby, Stan:

Absolutely. And in many cases the priority needs to be on carefully removing local regulation that potentially restricts local operators as opposed to creating new regulation.

Grant Blackley, Southern Cross Austereo:

Absolutely, but perhaps it should be less about trying to ???keep up' and more about regulating from the outset. The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) sets out and enforces a very clear and stringent set of regulations which radio and television broadcasters must adhere to. We believe this is critical to hold us to a high standard of practice and to provide a safe environment for audiences and advertisers. Meanwhile online and social media players remain largely unregulated, allowing them to exploit Australian consumers, all the while paying minimal Australian taxes. We also need to be thinking about appropriate regulation for emerging audio products such as smart speakers and in-car audio software, and we need to be thinking about it now. These new platforms are controlled by a similar small group of large international companies with substantial market power: Amazon, Google and Apple. They don't produce their own audio content but seek to monetise radio and podcast content produced by others. Radio plays an essential role in keeping people informed; local news, emergencies etc. Podcasting is growing in popularity and has a highly engaged and valuable audience. Content creators deserve an even regulatory playing field so they can earn a fair reward for entertaining and informing their audiences. We would encourage the ACCC consider recommending to ACMA and the Government a simple licence mechanism for all digital providers to operate in Australia - ensuring fair and reasonable oversight and consumer protections.

Cathy O'Connor, Nova Entertainment:

The faster the pace of disruption, the more important it becomes that regulators ensure a level and fair playing field for the Australian media against multinational tech giants. This does not exist now and the faster the disruption, the more unfair it becomes.

Graham Burke, Village Roadshow:

It is absolutely vital that regulators and legislation keep up given the emergence of colossal foreign competitors in our marketplace. This is crucial to protect Australian companies who employ our people. As a kid growing up, I remember Mad Magazine that had black spy and white spy and without protection the black spy will just envelope the universe!

Scott Lorson, FetchTV:

Media regulation is often necessary to ensure diverse and local voices, promote competition, protect consumers and combat piracy. Governments and regulators need to show strong leadership if they are to evolve regulation for an industry characterised by rapid change, competing commercial interests and strong media influence. Policy consistency is key, as is pragmatic and forward thinking regulation. The answers are often evident, but the will to action can be lacking.

Paul Dykzeul, Bauer Media Group:

It is absolutely critical. Every media company in Australia has, at some time, been subjected to this scrutiny and in my view; I fail to see why there should be any exception.

Ciaran Davis, Here There & Everywhere (Australian Radio Network):

We have an unbalanced media sector and the need for authorities to create an even playing field has never been more critical so that global media platforms (and yes, they are media companies!) are held to account and regulated to the same extent as Australian operators. Enforcement of an appropriate degree of regulatory controls is good for the media industry but it must be a level playing field. Commercially, domestic players invest significant resources to ensure compliance and this, in conjunction with the flow of advertising dollars towards global players, is putting pressure on our ability to continually invest in creating and delivering content to our audiences. It's incumbent on the regulator to keep up to ensure that our market approach and business models are judged within the context of the total market.

Name two pieces of content, technology or product (one from your organisation, one from a rival) that you admire, and why.

Andy Penn, Telstra:

Telstra TV. It is the market leading streaming product that brings together all the best services in one place with simple content discovery and cross platform search experience, along with a companion mobile app on IOS and Android. The interface is great, it gives you access to Free to Air, streaming and catch up and the search means you do not have to remember where content is, TTV can tell you what the options are to view it, in SD, HD, free or paid.

I am also a fan of is Amazon prime. It's a well-developed platform with a great interface providing seamless user experience and a great service. But another reason I like it is they eventually got Garth Brooks to go digital!

Tim Worner, Seven West Media:

From Seven Studios, I'd say ???Bride and Prejudice'. This upcoming season is absolutely brilliant and has the chance to be really noisy. From elsewhere, FaceTime is something that allows us to communicate a bit more personally with our kids wherever they might be.

Hugh Marks, Nine Entertainment Co:

For us the launch of 9Galaxy our TV automation buying platform has been a game changer for Nine with already 30 per cent of our off peak and multichannel inventory traded on the platform. This removes a significant administrative cost on the business, while simultaneously providing major efficiencies in trading for both us and our clients. We are continuing to invest in this platform and will continue to ramp up its capabilities as the market moves to simplify the TV buying process. A rival's content? I'd have to say Seven's horse racing coverage. It's world class.

Paul Anderson, Network Ten:

I am a huge fan of ten daily, our new mobile friendly website that delivers short form content across News, Sport and Entertainment. One of its best features is The Bachelor TL:DRs ("Too Long Didn't Read"). Matt Whitehead is ten daily's Senior Entertainment Reporter and someone had the brilliant idea to put a camera on him talking about each ep of The Bachelor, hilarious. I'm loving ten daily's The Bachelorette TL: DRs now too. I love the way voice-controlled virtual assistants like Amazon Alexa are changing our world. They not only cleverly connect devices at home but they also provide excellent collaboration opportunities for companies to extend their brands and services in a different way. We've partnered with Amazon Alexa, for example, to deliver the latest Ten News flash briefings to people throughout the day. They can just call out and say "Alexa, what's my news?" to hear the latest headlines. How cool is that?

Michael Miller, News Corp:

The Australian's recent podcast series The Teacher's Pet is a stunning example of original, unique content that attracted extraordinary audience numbers - more than 25 million downloads. It is testament to the compelling investigative journalism of Hedley Thomas that this series proved so groundbreaking and such a global success. It is now second on the iTunes podcast chart to My Father The Murderer, created by journalist Nina Young of our digital women's network - whimn.com.au. The AFR's Rich List, modelled on The Sunday Times Rich List in the UK, was a terrific franchise created by John Stensholt. We liked it so much we hired him. Watch this space.

Greg Hywood, Fairfax Media:

Our newspapers and digital sites remain a daily miracle. The Americans. A choice binge.

Patrick Delany, Foxtel:

The technology I admire most is our magical iQ4 set top box and the smart remotes that are about to join it. The iQ4 is the monster truck of set top boxes and the sharpest brain you can have in your home. The world of content it can seamlessly take you to, including 4K pictures, is next level amazing. The other products you have to watch with a mixture of admiration and trepidation is games like Fortnite. The audience and engagement they achieve is extraordinary and the hold they have on some young people's lives is troubling.

Mike Sneesby, Stan:

Well, it's pretty clear that Video-On-Demand is leading an evolution for our eyes and ears, but I'm seriously in awe of how Food-on-Demand is leading an evolution for our bellies. UberEats isn't a rival, but I'm both obsessed and fascinated by the way all this food just turns up at your door. It's really fun to watch an episode of Get Shorty (my current Stan favourite) and see if I can get a sushi platter, a pizza and a burrito to arrive in unison, all while the closing credits are rolling.

Grant Blackley, Southern Cross Austereo:

We are incredibly proud of PodcastOne Australia, which produces and distributes the original podcasts of more than 50 Australian creators, and has accomplished more than 60 million downloads since launching in July 2017. It has rapidly become the leading commercial original podcasting platform in Australia. PodcastOne's premium original content model is inspired by Netflix's own archetype, so we certainly see great merit in what Netflix has done for its audience. There is an increasing appetite for original on-demand content and we're excited to continue expanding our already diverse content state, while growing understanding and uptake of the medium among trade and consumers.

Cathy O'Connor, Nova Entertainment:

For a refreshingly honest and authentic talk radio show, our FIVEaa team of David & Will (Dave Penberthy and Will Goodings) is a must listen. The show's sustained audience growth in Adelaide shows that intelligent talk does resonate with audiences and challenges the notion that you have to "shock" or "rant" to connect in commercial talk. From the broader market, The Australian's Teacher's Pet podcast is the best example of the powerful "lean-in" experience of podcasting and a demonstration that Australian audio content can compete on a global scale.

Graham Burke, Village Roadshow:

In terms of content, technology or product, it is simply a question of the wide array of innovation that is just part and parcel of running every aspect of our businesses in 2018. Singling out one area of admiration is the ability to know our customer, where they live and knowing what they want.

Scott Lorson, FetchTV:

The reality is that it has taken contributions across our entire ecosystem to usher in this Golden Era for entertainment viewing. Consumers enjoy unprecedented access to premium programming along with new tools to help search, discover and access that content. They can also view that content on bigger screens with better sound quality and higher resolution, both at home and on the go. As the master aggregator, Fetch are proud to play a central role in simplifying and enriching the entertainment experience for millions of Aussie viewers.

Paul Dykzeul, Bauer Media Group:

Female Futures has been a real success story for us. It's a forward-thinking collection of initiatives designed to support Australian women. We made a commitment to use our influential voice to ignite positive change for women. Since August this year, 36 magazine brands had been running a "No Gender Selective Tax" campaign in support of removing the GST. This involved editorial and advertising content across all major brands as well as an influencer campaign across social media. We were able to reach around 9 million voters who were directly affected by this sort of policy before the government decided to make the change. Looking internationally, Hello Sunshine has created an interesting new media model for a new age. It's centred on storytelling with women at the core, wherever women are spending their time and attention. They have built a deep and engaged community across film, television, audio, book clubs, digital and live shows to name just a few. It's driven by the authenticity and values of its champion, Reese Witherspoon.

Ciaran Davis, Here There & Everywhere (Australian Radio Network):

iHeartradio is our digital entertainment and music streaming platform that now reaches over 1 million registered users. The platform complements our broader digital and social offerings, allowing a seamless content experience for our audiences on whichever platform they choose to consume live radio and other forms of audio including on-demand music and podcasts. The rich data set that we are building will allow for greater personalisation and drive new commercial opportunities for us. Technology is opening up many new and exciting opportunities to consume content. I recently visited a volumetric capture studio and was blown away. It's VR/MR on steroids and the possibilities and creative content experiences are endless.

urn:contentItem:5F9R-3661-JCMN-Y1RV-00000-00"Full Speed Back To The Late Nineteenth Century"2015-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:43ZLexisNexis"Full Speed Back To The Late Nineteenth Century"noreply@blogger.com (Ted McLaughlin)

Feb 16, 2015( jobsanger: http://jobsanger.blogspot.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;<nl/>   http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-ecUqWFD_fmU/VOEpEofMYsI/AAAAAAABM4E/qtqfv10eFaY/s1600/free%2Bmarket%2Bfix.jpg   http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_WR9zaW3dBY/VOEpKAmGMYI/AAAAAAABM4M/lolnPdCjzWo/s1600/reich.jpgLibertarians and conservative Republicans (and their "think tanks") agree on one thing. They both believe in "free enterprise" -- a free and unregulated market (a capitalism with no rules). The Libertarians can't do much about it, but the conservative Republicans have been trying to force their free market utopia on this country for decades (since the Reagan administration).<nl/>

And they have been fairly successful in that effort, by giving unregulated capitalism a new name -- "Trickle-Down" economics. They had a lot of Americans fooled into believing that removing regulations on corporations and financial institutions, destroying (or at least weakening) labor unions, and cutting taxes for the rich and corporations would be beneficial for all Americans.<nl/>They lied. What it really did was shrink the middle class, stagnate wages for most Americans, induce the exporting of good American jobs, increase poverty, and cause the biggest recession in this country since the Great Depression (a recession that many Americans still haven't recovered from). That doesn't matter to the Republicans -- who only care about putting more money into the pockets of their rich friends and donors. They could care less about ordinary Americans, and because of that, they still cling to their failed economic policy.<nl/>Former Labor Secretary Robert Reich says they are sending America back to the late Nineteenth Century[1], and he has a point. The Republicans would love to replay that time in American history -- a time when Big Business ruled, and workers had no rights. Here is what he had to say:<nl/>My recent column[2] about the growth of on-demand jobs like Uber making life less predictable and secure for workers unleashed a small barrage of criticism from some who contend that workers get what they're worth in the market.A Forbes Magazine contributor, for example, writes[3] that jobs exist only 'when both employer and employee are happy with the deal being made.' So if the new jobs are low-paying and irregular, too bad.Much the same argument was voiced in the late nineteenth century over alleged 'freedom of contract.[4]' Any deal between employees and workers was assumed to be fine if both sides voluntarily agreed to it. It was an era when many workers were 'happy' to toil twelve-hour days in sweat shops for lack of any better alternative. It was also a time of great wealth for a few and squalor for many. And of corruption, as the lackeys of robber barons deposited sacks of cash on the desks of pliant legislators.Finally, after decades of labor strife and political tumult, the twentieth century brought an understanding that capitalism requires minimum standards[5] of decency and fairness - workplace safety, a minimum wage, maximum hours (and time-and-a-half for overtime), and a ban on child labor.We also learned that capitalism needs a fair balance of power between big corporations and workers. We achieved that through antitrust laws that reduced the capacity of giant corporations to impose their will, and labor laws that allowed workers to organize and bargain collectively. By the 1950s, when 35 percent [6]of private-sector workers belonged to a labor union, they were able to negotiate higher wages and better working conditions than employers would otherwise have been 'happy' to provide.But now we seem to be heading back to nineteenth century.Corporations are shifting full-time work onto temps, free-lancers, and contract workers who fall outside the labor protections established decades ago.The nation's biggest corporations and Wall Street banks are larger and more potent than ever. And labor union membership has shrunk to fewer than 7 percent of private-sector workers.So it's not surprising we're once again hearing that workers are worth no more than what they can get in the market.But as we should have learned a century ago, markets don't exist in nature. They're created by human beings. The real question is how they're organized and for whose benefit.In the late nineteenth century they were organized for the benefit of a few at the top. But by the middle of the twentieth century they were organized for the vast majority.During the thirty years after the end of World War II, as the economy doubled in size, so did the wages of most Americans — along with improved hours and working conditions.Yet since around 1980, even though the economy has doubled once again (the Great Recession notwithstanding), the wages most Americans have stagnated. And their benefits and working conditions have deteriorated. This isn't because most Americans are worth less. In fact, worker productivityhttp://www.bls.gov/lpc/ is higher[7] than ever. It's because big corporations, Wall Street, and some enormously rich individuals have gained political power to organize the market in ways that have enhanced their wealth while leaving most Americans behind.That includes trade agreements[8] protecting the intellectual property of large corporations and Wall Street's financial assets, but not American jobs and wages.Bailouts of big Wall Street banks and their executives and shareholders when they can't pay what they owe, but not of homeowners who can't meet their mortgage payments. Bankruptcy protection for big corporations, allowing them to shed their debts, including labor contracts. But no bankruptcy protection for college graduates over-burdened with student debts.Antitrust leniency toward a vast swathe of American industry - including Big Cable (Comcast, AT...Time-Warner), Big Tech (Amazon, Google), Big Pharma, the largest Wall Street banks, and giant retailers (Walmart).But less tolerance toward labor unions — as workers trying to form unions are fired with impunity, and more states adopt so-called 'right-to-work' laws[9] that undermine unions. We seem to be heading full speed back to the late nineteenth century. So what will be the galvanizing force for change this time? <nl/>   http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-utIbWwuyGQk/VOFL_CzdefI/AAAAAAABM58/pro9qJH1YfY/s1600/tom%2Btoles%2Bcartoon.jpgThis cartoon is by Tom Toles in The Washington Post.<nl/> [ 1]:   http://robertreich.org/post/110555525570 [ 2]:   http://robertreich.org/post/109894095095 [ 3]:   http://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffreydorfman/2015/02/07/robert-reich-former-labor-secretary-does-not-understand-labor-markets/ [ 4]:   https://books.google.com/books?id=YGYnOoOJTXcC...PA10...=PA10...late+nineteenth+century+freedom+of+contract...rce=bl...=V4HIB5FAtD...=gTkEuvWwCC6j3nBxZjzKHjMbkAU...en...X...3fjYVJq2EcH6oQSEvYLwBw...=0CD0Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage...ate%20nineteenth%20century%20freedom%20of%20contract...alse [ 5]:   http://www.dissentmagazine.org/online_articles/the-bare-minimum-labor-standards-and-american-inequality [ 6]:   http://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/24/business/union-membership-drops-despite-job-growth.html?_r=0 [ 7]:   http://www.bls.gov/lpc/ [ 8]:   http://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jan/20/barack-obama-trans-pacific-partnership-republicans [ 9]:   http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/03/what-are-right-to-work-laws

urn:contentItem:5J9S-K3K1-JCPJ-W3PW-00000-00Fullstack Academy-whose grads land at Facebook and Google-acquires Chicago coding school pioneer2016-03-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:42ZLexisNexisFullstack Academy-whose grads land at Facebook and Google-acquires Chicago coding school pioneerTeresa Novellino

Fullstack Academy, the New York City-based company that runs a coding bootcamp, announced today that it has acquired The Starter League, the pioneering Chicago code school that launched in 2011 as Code Academy.

Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Fullstack Academy cofounders David Yang and Nimit Maru plan to run the two companies as separate entities, but will unify their pricing structures and borrow back and forth between the two curriculums. Fullstack Academy will open its second school in Chicago in an office within 1871, the city's digital startup hub. (Fullstack's first location is at 5 Hanover Square in Manhattan's Financial District.)

"We are not going to be competing - we are one company now," Maru said in a phone interview. "We're going to be working with them in Chicago, where they built a really great brand...Starter League has an array of high-curriculum software that we'll be able to take advantage of and a strong alumni base in Chicago. We'll share cultural practices, too."

Starter League CEO Neal Sales-Griffin, who cofounded the company with Mike McGee, will stay on for the transition.

Fullstack, a Y Combinator-backed firm, has a team of about 34 full-time employees, while The Starter League has relied upon contractors. Those Chicago-area contractors will be offered full-time jobs if they would like to stay on as employees, Maru said, but Fullstack's model is to hire people only as employees. "Not everyone will decide to join," he predicted.

Coding schools have become a big business. While Code Academy is credited with being among the first, there are now 100 such boot camps for coders around the world. Course Report, in its 2015 market size report, forecasted that 16,056 students would graduate from coding schools in 2015, a 138 percent increase from 6,740 students in 2014. Coding bootcamps were expected to generate $172 million in tuition revenue in 2015, more than double the $52 million they raked in for 2014.

Fullstack cofounder David Yang said that the company has not taken in any additional venture funding or investment since its Y Combinator days. It is a for-profit business, but it is regulated as an educational institution by the states in which it operates.

"We really want to build a Fullstack and we care a lot about sustainability. Educational institutions can last for tens of hundreds of years, and we want to be doing the right thing," Yang said.

Fullstack graduates - 400 have gone through the program since it launched in 2014-are typically amateur coders who might have taken a class or two previously but are not engineers. This has not hurt their chances of getting a job at a big firm. Alumni have gone on to work at big tech companies including Facebook (Nasdaq: FB), Google (Nasdaq: GOOG), Dropbox and Palantir. The 17-week full-time immersive class costs $16,810, while a flex immersive program that is part-time and takes twice as long is priced at $15,080.

It's pricey, yet can be cheaper than a four-year degree in computer science.

"The way I would compare it is it's like having a major in biology versus medical school," Maru said, adding that the latter "focuses a lot on the theory but not the practice of how employees are using this in the real world."

As a result of the acquisition, The Starter League's prices will be placed in line with those of Fullstack, Maru said. Backed by Basecamp, which is the birthplace of Ruby on Rails, the Starter League has graduated students who tend to go on to start their own companies. Among the 1,400 people who have been through the program since its inception, founders have started WeDeliver (which was acquired), ReliefWatch, BallotReady, Launchpad Lab, Know Your Company, as well as future coding bootcamps, such as MakerSquare (acquired), Bitmaker, and DevPoint Labs.

Fullstack Academy is currently accepting applications to its full-time software engineering immersive in Chicago via its website. The remote component of this program, Foundations, will start in May, while on-premise classes will start in June.

urn:contentItem:5NJD-65N1-JBK8-90GG-00000-00Full stream ahead Warner Music near royalty deal with Spotify ON THE MONEY2017-05-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:42ZLexisNexisAll EditionsPg. 72Full stream ahead Warner Music near royalty deal with Spotify ON THE MONEYCLAIRE ATKINSON

Fresh off a pact to license music to YouTube, Warner Music boss Steve Cooper is turning his attention to music streamer Spotify - and a deal could be signed by June.

Sources tell On the Money that Warner and Spotify are getting thisclose to a new royalty agreement. If inked, Daniel Ek's Spotify would be on the way to its long-planned IPO - expected in the final quarter of 2017.

Spotify signed new long-term deals with Universal Music Group and with independent music representative Merlin last month.

Spotify has yet to get Sony Music to the table. The streamer has been looking for labels to take a cut in their fees so Spotify has a path to profitability. A source said: " We're looking for a deal where both sides share in the risks and rewards." Spotify is offering up more data and a greater share of guaranteed revenue. It currently gives 55 percent of all revenue back to the labels.

The labels do not want to be solely reliant on the big tech giants such as Apple, Google and Amazon for revenue.

Spotify has proven it is willing to be more flexible about launching new music on its paid tier instead of giving it away for free. It's also got a sizable lead on music streamers, with more than 50 million paid subscribers. Spotify confirmed it hired banks Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Allen & Co. to advise on an IPO.

Whether Spotify's big valuation can aid interest in Pandora remains to be seen.

Tweet endorsement

Alphabet may be breathing a big sigh of relief.

Interim Federal Trade Commission Chair Maureen Ohlhausen has risen to become the favorite to land the permanent spot in what would be a surprise, a source told our Josh Kosman.

Ohlhausen was an FTC commissioner when the regulator voted in 2013 to close an investigation into Google's alleged monopolistic activity.

The former favorite to be FTC Chair, Utah Attorney General Sean Reyes, was far more likely to open a probe into whether Alphabet improperly pressured mobile phone makers to install Google apps on their phones, sources said.

Former FTC Commissioner Josh Wright, who was on President Trump's Department of Justice transition team, may have tipped the scales for Ohlhausen in a May 9 tweet stating that she "will make an excellent chair" and the appointment to the position was "long overdue."

Wright has not always been friendly with the fellow Republican Ohlhausen, the source said, making his endorsement even more noteworthy.

Trump would find it easier to name Ohlhausen, since she would not require Senate confirmation as she has already been confirmed.

Ohmmmmm

May is National Meditation month, and that seems to be the topic on everyone's mind.

Jennifer Gould Keil reports that supermodel Gisele Bundchen (pictured) told a crowd at the David Lynch Foundation's Women of Vision Humanitarian Awards that she meditates whenever she can, even in the back seat of a New York City taxi.

Robin Roberts, a co-anchor of ABC's "Good Morning America," also told emcee Rosanna Scotto that she now gets up at 3:15 a.m. instead of 4 a.m. - to meditate. Her co-host George Stephanopoulos also practices transcendental meditation, or TM.

Roberts and Bundchen were among the honorees at the awards dinner.

Meditation may even have helped actor Leonardo DiCaprio win his first Oscar - a prize that had long eluded him - as he meditated with Montreal-based expert Lynne Goldberg while he was filming "The Revenant" in Calgary.

Goldberg is in town to spread the meditation mantra - and her app, OMG. I Can Meditate!

While the transcendental meditation taught through the Lynch Foundation, which also uses meditation as a tool to help veterans and victims of sexual and domestic abuse, touts 20 minutes twice a day, Goldberg has an app for 1-, 2- and 5-minute meditation options.

On the 'Stick'

Mark Aaron James, an indie singer and musician, released his newest album, the aptly named "My Mighty MAJic Stick," last week.

The recording is the first nationally distributed album that is physically available only on USB drive (in addition to online downloads and streaming platforms).

The flash drive is shaped like a credit card and offers an additional 2 GB of memory.

James says of the format, "With computers rarely incorporating CD drives anymore, and most consumers listening on digital players, it seemed a logical format to experiment with. It's exciting to try something new."

GISELE BUNDCHEN. (Getty Images)
