urn:contentItem:5VJD-Y4W1-DXH2-61X9-00000-00Full Year 2018 Tarsus Group PLC Earnings Call - Final2019-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:43ZLexisNexis022719a12357059.759Full Year 2018 Tarsus Group PLCEarnings Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* Daniel P. O'Brien

Tarsus Group plc- Group Finance Director, Member of Executive Board & Executive Director

* James Douglas Emslie

Tarsus Group plc- Group MD, Member of Executive Board & Executive Director

Conference Call Participants

* Christopher Anton Giles Collett

Deutsche Bank AG, Research Division - Research Analyst

* Fiona Catherine Orford-Williams

Edison Investment Research Limited - Director & Sector Head Media

* Gareth Rhys Davies

Numis Securities Limited, Research Division - Director of Media Equity Research

* Ian Richard Whittaker

Liberum Capital Limited, Research Division - Head of European Media Research

Presentation

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE, GROUP MD, MEMBER OF EXECUTIVE BOARD & EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, TARSUS GROUP PLC: I'd like to say welcome, everybody, to the Tarsus's 2018 results. A year ago, you may remember we did our results during the Beast from the East. And this year, we've got predicted to be the hottest day on record in February. And hopefully, that's reflective, in our view, of our outlook.

In terms of the agenda, I'll run through some of the highlights and then pass over to Dan, and he will go through the financial and operating review, and then I'll come back and go through the strategy and the outlook.

So straight into the highlights.

In 2018, we've had a strong operational and financial performance, which is very pleasing as it's the first year of our next phase of our strategy, Quickening the Pace 2. I'll go through that in a little bit more detail later. But in terms of the numbers, very pleased with our like-for-like revenues, up 9%. Our buyers, which is one of the key metrics we focus on internally, up 10%, delivering an EPS of 17.5p, which has allowed us to increase the dividend by 10% up to 11p.

It's also been a busy year in terms of building out the portfolio. We've had 19 new launches. We've made 6 acquisitions, and 3 of those have been increasing our exposure to existing investments in buying more of those businesses. And with that, I'll hand over to Dan.

DANIEL P. O'BRIEN, GROUP FINANCE DIRECTOR, MEMBER OF EXECUTIVE BOARD & EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, TARSUS GROUP PLC: Thank you, Doug, and good morning, everybody. I want to spend about 15 minutes running through the financial and operational review, and the handout you've got sets out definitions, some terms we're using this morning. And just to note that the presentation and an audio recording of this meeting will be available on our website later.

As Doug said, 2018 was another successful year for us and a very busy year. And so we'll just crack on and look at the numbers.

So starting with revenues. Normal impact here of biennials, acquisitions and foreign currency. But as always, it's the underlying revenue performance that's important, and we're really pleased with the like-for-like growth of 9%.

The trend we're seeing in our revenues is reflected in our profits, which had also grown well, and the overall profit margin staying pretty consistent, which is what we expected.

The headline tax rate of 16%, actually at the low end of our expectations, and that was due to some deferred tax losses being utilized in the year. That it's relatively low rate reflects the geographical spread of our business.

We have a strong EPS performance. Now that's after reflecting the impact of the equity raise in September last year. The EPS grew 17.5p, that is 17.5p a share, up 15% from 2016. And this has allowed us to continue our dividend growth with a 10% increase this year to 11p a share, the eighth consecutive year of dividend increase and subject to maintaining sensible levels of cover, which for us is around 2x average overall 2-year cycle. We look to maintain this progressive dividend policy.

And our financial position remains very strong. We ended the year with net debt of GBP 79 million, and that equates to gearing of 2x net debt-to-EBITDA measured over a 24-month rolling cycle. And that's back in line with our medium-term target range for gearing.

So moving on to revenues.

Last year, we had GBP 118 million of revenue. In terms of biennial events, the even years, it's a quieter year, there's GBP 26 million difference in a smaller biennial year. In 2017, we had 6 biennial events; this year, just 3: Labelexpo series in Americas, in India as well as MEBA in Dubai.

In terms of acquisitions, this year relatively small impacts relate principally to AMB and E.J. Krause, which were consolidated from the point of acquisition onwards.

You can see here of the overall impacts on revenues from foreign currency changes. These are negative GBP 3 million. The main driver here is the Turkish lira, which devalued significantly across the year. The U.S. dollar was also a small net negative against previous years. However, due to the phasing of profits across the year, the impacts on profits is less significant. It's slightly negative, but it's not material overall to the results of the group. We then have that underlying revenue growth, which is carried on our strong track record, up 9% on a like-for-like basis at constant currencies. And we finished the year with revenues of just under GBP 100 million.

This slide shows the geographical shape of our business, which we've driven through our strategy. The top pie chart on the left shows that we're now focused largely on the U.S. and Asia. We've got 2/3 of our revenues coming from the world's largest event markets, the Americas and China. The bottom pie chart shows our currency exposure remain principally exposed to the U.S. dollar with 2/3 of our 2019 revenues expected to be U.S. dollar denominated.

The map really highlights where we're deploying our resource. It's into those high-growth geographies in the Americas and Asia. And it's also an obvious point, but it's one still worth mentioning that this slide really does illustrate that we have very little exposure to Brexit.

So let's turn now to the results by geography, and we'll start with the Americas.

The biennial event here is Labelexpo Americas, the event held in Chicago. We've seen some impressive growth across the Americas segment, and that includes both the U.S. and Mexico. Some of this growth comes from acquisitions, but across the division, we had 9% like-for-like growth in the Americas. Historically, this division has been very profitable and has had good margins, and we've maintained those margins this year. And this year's pleasing as Connect has grown well, and their revenue comes in at slightly lower margins. We've also been adding resource into the U.S. team to help drive growth. So a good performance on profits from the Americas.

Just now looking at the operations in a bit more detail.

The Medical business, growth there continues overall with particularly strong performances from our preventative medicine business, which closed the year with a record show in our December event in Las Vegas, and also in our cardiovascular business. The dermatology and PAINWeek business units had a slower time in 2018. That's driven by the drug pipeline in those areas being a bit weaker. But both have improved outlook for 2019. So we're seeing the benefit of having a diversified portfolio across 4 clinical areas in Medical division, and the outlook for this unit as a whole is very -- for '19 is very good.

In OFFPRICE, our discount clothing show, it had a steady performance in what is a really tough retail environment.

In Mexico, we purchased the remaining 50% of the E.J. Krause business. We now own 100% of that. We also added Expo Restaurantes to the portfolio during the year. In trading terms, the portfolio in Mexico performed very well across the board, and the integration has gone very smoothly. We believe that Mexico has great potential and is an interesting opportunity for us, and Doug will go into that in a bit more detail later.

Our Connect business had a strong year with good growth being driven by launches, 6 new events this year, making 11 since we acquired the business. We also acquired the eTourism Summit, which performed in line with our expectations.

Finally, for the Americas, the labels event in Chicago was a fantastic event, grew really well and had a very impressive rebook rate at 83%.

Moving now to Asia. This includes the results from Southeast Asia and China. And the biennial events here are the Labelexpo event in India and also, for the first time, in Bangkok.

Revenues here have grown well across the division, like-for-like growth at 14%. And the profits here also have been strong. And again, that's pleasing because we've put resource into this division in order to drive our replication program.

Overall, China had a very good year with strong growth, as I mentioned. China now forms a more significant part of the group. Standout performances were our Hometex, our -- the Hometex store show, and also Intex, which is our joint venture with the Chinese government. Both had very strong performances, showing good like-for-like growth.

Southeast Asia also performed well with 8 launches across the region, helping to drive strong growth. The highlight of the year for that region, though, was really Bangkok, which was an outstanding launch, I mean, the best launch in Tarsus' history.

Finishing now with the results by division, going through EMEA.

The results this year are smaller without the large biennials coming through which just take place in the odd years. The revenues in this division have been hit hard by currency changes, and also the underlying revenues were down 6% on a like-for-like basis. And in terms of the profits, the division made its full profit for the year, and that decrease reflects the revenue performance and the gearing coming through.

In terms of the operations, trading in Dubai were generally solid with good performances from GESS and the smaller aerospace events. MEBA's performance was impacted by lower spending in the region on private jets, notably from Saudi customers. In Turkey, we had similar patterns to last year with the larger shows performing well. But overall, Turkish revenues were down 8% on a like-for-like basis on constant currencies. But the main story in Turkey was a very weak Turkish lira, which is down over 40% for the year. But this really demonstrates the benefit of having a diversified portfolio for the whole of Tarsus in that despite tricky conditions in Turkey, this didn't really have a material impact on the group as a whole.

So finishing off with a couple of slides on net debt.

We started the year with GBP 85 million of net debt, and we raised GBP 24 million with a share placing in September. We got the normal outflows in respect to dividends, interest and tax as well as the cash impact of exceptional items. We also have the impact of acquisitions and deferred income with payments for a total of GBP 23 million, the largest items here being the acquisitions of the 25% shares in AMB and SIUF as well as buying the remainder of Krause. We then have that very strong cash coming in from operations of GBP 30 million. And a really pleasing feature of that is the contribution we got from our joint venture companies where cash received was ahead of profits. And so we finished the end of 2018 with net debt of GBP 79 million.

Cash and net debt was in line with where we expected to be. Our gearing finished the year at 2x net debt-to-EBITDA, and this is in line with our target range of 1.5 to 2x. And that continues to be our medium-term target range for the group's gearing.

Finally, just a quick word on our bank facilities.

We increased our total facilities in December up to GBP 150 million. This comprises GBP 120 million RCF with a club of 4 banks: HSBC, and Bank of Ireland, who we've banked with for a number of years, now joined by NatWest and Citibank. We've also made our first entry into the bond markets with a GBP 30 million, 7-year, fixed interest rate sterling bond with (inaudible). This is the first-class panel of banks and provides a great platform to help with any further increases in debt capacity should we need it. The terms on our facilities are broadly similar to previous bank deals other than we now have a slightly higher gearing covenant of 3.25x. And whilst I said our medium-term target remains unchanged, this high gearing covenant does give us a little bit more flexibility in capacity in the short term. So overall, we're really pleased with these facilities in that they provide a great platform for supporting our Quickening the Pace 2 strategy.

So to conclude, a very good set of results that we're pleased with, and the results demonstrate the success of our Quickening the Pace strategy and as evidenced by that sustained dividend growth. That means we're well placed to continue our growth, and Doug will tell us more about that now.

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Thanks, Dan.

So a year ago, we announced the next phase of the strategy, Quickening the Pace 2. As we said at the time, this was evolutionary rather than revolutionary, continuing to focus on growth and building scale but building scale at the event level. And in terms of growth, continuing to focus on the 3 pillars: driving organic growth from the existing business, carrying on the replication program and, where we found good opportunities, adding to the portfolio by way of bolt-on acquisition.

So let's just take a look at the performance over the period.

What you can see in terms of revenue growth is consistent performance over the period right at the top end of our peer group. So that's very pleasing. Just to reiterate what I said in the opening remarks, for us internally, it's really buyer growth that we're excited. This shows the strength of our brands going forward, and 10% is right at the top of our own internal KPI. So very pleased with what the team has achieved in the past year.

In terms of the replication program, we've continued to find opportunities, and this also drives our acquisition strategy because we're looking for platforms that are going to continue to give us opportunities to launch products. It's not a question of just buying to increase earnings per share, it's buying where we can add value. And we continue to see opportunities within the portfolio today to launch more products. And in 2019, and we're projecting another 12 launches. So that's very encouraging.

In terms of acquisitions activity, 6 is higher than we would normally do. Three of those, as I said earlier, we're increasing our shareholdings in existing investments. But really since Informa bought UBM a year ago or announced the acquisition a year ago, we've seen the market stimulated. And I think in over 10 years, I've never seen an acquisition pipeline that we've got today as strong. So the market for the type of acquisitions that we like in terms of smaller, medium size is very strong at the moment.

So in terms of looking at the shape of the portfolio and how it's changed, I think this slide really demonstrates the active portfolio management. We bought, we've launched, we've closed, we've sold. And what's really, really encouraging for us in terms of actually demonstrating the Tarsus culture, it's entrepreneurial, it's fast moving. If it doesn't work, we move on. If it does work, we put in more resource.

And in terms of the launches and the closures, they don't quite correlate because some of the closures are from existing products before the launches. So of those 70 products that we've launched, today 70% of those are still running, so that's very encouraging, against an internal target of after 3 years of 50%.

So in terms of what this mean, a year ago I said 2017 was the inflection point. It's where we moved from investment into actually generating returns. And I'm very pleased that that's come through strongly in 2018, where nearly 7% of our revenues are being generated from these launches. 2018 is obviously the slightly smaller year, but it's still very impressive and it's contributing a sensible amount of profit at GBP 1.5 million. The Labelexpo launch in Bangkok was a major contributor to that. We're very pleased with that, one of the best launches we've done in 20 years. That event is every 2 years. It doesn't repeat in 2019. So in terms of what the schedule would look like in a year's time, I would say it probably is sort of flatter and then in '20 stepping up again as the biennials kick back in and the growth continues through into '20. So very pleasing that it's now a material part of the business financially.

In terms of the KPIs, there is nothing new here. It's still the same 3 KPIs. In terms of revenues, it's 9%; buyers, 10%, as we've said in 2018; and in earnings per share, it's actually 8%, and there's a slight adjustment there on a like-for-like basis because we have Plastimagen in Mexico, which only takes place every 18 months and actually did not take place in 2018. So very pleased that actually, we met all of our targets in '18.

In terms of looking at the business going forward, we've previously spoken about the growth drivers, and we're focused on 3: Shenzhen, Connect, labels and aerospace. And I'll go through each of those in turn now.

In terms of Shenzhen, this is going to be driven by the building of the new venue. We currently are the largest international organizer in Shenzhen, but 4 of our 5 largest shows are wall bound in the existing 100,000-meter venue that's there. The new venue is going to be 5x that size. So 500,000 square meters. The venue is scheduled to open in September of this year. I'm actually out there next week, so I'll see how it's going, but I'm led to believe that might be slightly behind. So for us, because our shows are very, very congregated in the early part of the year, it's likely that we are not going to go move and see the benefit of that space growth until '21.

In terms of the 3 major products that we have in Shenzhen, Hometex is the largest, and that show takes place next week. It's wall bound, but I'm very pleased that it's going to be up mid-single-digit in terms of revenue growth. So the team have done well to get growth out of that event, and we've got quite a sizable waiting list for when we move to the new venue.

AAITF is actually taking place as we speak. It is also wall bound in a very competitive market. Again, we're looking to grow that with the move to the venue.

And then finally, SIUF, our underwear business, continues to grow well, and we bought a majority, which allows us to move our own management in there to actually put in our normal sales and marketing systems, and we're seeing the benefit of that in a very short order with the upcoming April show growing strongly.

So Connect, a business that we acquired 2 years ago focused on the travel market, predominantly in the U.S. So we're seeing growth being driven really by a good economic situation in America and the investments that were made in hotel stock primarily in 2013 coming through onstream. We've launched a lot in this division, 11 in total. And one of the major new businesses that we launched was in the leisure market and in marketing, and the second edition of those events took place last week, I'm very pleased to see that they actually grew quite strongly from their launch events. And at the same time, we launched our first show into business travel, which, again, went well in its first outing. So we're seeing good growth. We've added a lot to that portfolio in the last 2 years, but we're continuing to see opportunities and we've got 4 new events for this year as well. So we're very pleased with the growth we're seeing coming through from Connect. And it's a classic case study of the type of business that we like. It's a platform where we could add a lot and launch a lot around it.

Moving on to Labelexpo. It is our oldest brand. It was a brand that we started Tarsus with 20 years ago, and it's coming up for its 40th anniversary. But we're continuing to see very strong growth from the big events, and the big event this year is in Europe, in Brussels, where we're seeing strong revenue growth. That's being driven primarily from the mass market adoption of digital technologies. But we're also seeing the industry continuing to innovate and move into related areas in the printing and packaging sector. And in response to that, the team have come up with a new launch program called brand print, where we're launching in 2020 4 new shows starting off in May of next year in Bangkok. And we're very excited about this opportunity to accelerate our growth from replications.

Finally, aerospace. We have the big show this year in November in Dubai, and it's very much on track to be the biggest air show in its history. And what we're also seeing is opportunities to add new components to the show. And in particular, we're seeing strong growth from 3 of those: the space sector from Cargo and from GATM, which is all about air traffic control. So the team are continuing to innovate. We're continuing to see good growth. And these are opportunities in the off years to actually run them separately. So when the air show is on, we'll run them concurrently and we'll run them separately in the off years.

And then, finally, we've added to the portfolio, which is the first time we've done this since we actually bought the Dubai business in 2007, where we bought a business from streamline where the first major show under our ownership comes up next month in Abu Dhabi, where we'll be launching the space event, which is going very strongly.

So I thought I'll just make a few remarks about Mexico and our major move there in 2018. It was the largest single acquisition that we did in 2018. And I think, again, it's a good case study of how we attack a new market. 4 years ago, we went in, in a 50-50 joint venture on the 2 largest products of E.J. Krause. E.J. Krause is the largest exhibition organizer in Mexico. That went well. And about 18 months ago, we expanded that to be 50% of their total show portfolio. It's gone well. We've got to know the portfolio. We've got to know the market. We've got to know the teams. And we moved that to be 100%. So we are now the largest organizer in Mexico.

We like Mexico principally because it's highly fragmented. Also, its close links with the U.S. help drive the portfolio that we've got, which is really being driven in 2 areas in terms of the industrial side, and a lot of that is coming from international participation from exhibitors, but also domestic demand, particularly in our foods and beauty products. We were pleased last week to announce to the trade press that actually, on our beauty product, we bought out our minority partner. We did a long-term deal with Expo Guadalajara. And also, we launched a second show, which will take place in November this year in Monterrey, which, again, is just another example of getting in there and adding value and expanding the portfolio.

So moving on now to outlook.

2019 has got off to a good start. Our bookings are strong across the portfolio. And as we stand here today, we're not seeing any cyclical economic weakness. In terms of the 3 regions, in terms of our bookings, overall we're up 10%, but it splits 8% coming out of the Americas, 8% in Asia and 12% coming out of EMEA. And that 12% is driven by 2 things: firstly, the strength of the big biennials, Dubai Airshow and Labelexpo; but also a very strong recovery from our Turkish portfolio. So we're very pleased with what we're seeing in terms of the existing business. We're also seeing continued good opportunities to launch new shows, 12 that are in the pipeline, and also a strong acquisition pipeline.

So to finish off, I think what we've seen is continued good, consistent, top-of-peer group performance in 2018. It's been a good start to the first year of our Quickening the Pace 2 strategy. Got good, strong forward bookings based broadly across the portfolio. And in that confidence, I think we're signaling that with the 10% increase in the dividend.

And with that, I'd like to move on to any questions that you may have.

Questions and Answers

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: So the first question, I think Ian was first. Do you want to say who you are and where you're from?

IAN RICHARD WHITTAKER, HEAD OF EUROPEAN MEDIA RESEARCH, LIBERUM CAPITAL LIMITED, RESEARCH DIVISION: Sorry folks. That's (inaudible). It's Ian Whittaker from Liberum. Just 2 questions actually. First of all, if you go back to Slide 21 and you look at the sort of buyer growth versus the revenue growth, certainly over the past 4 years, so the 2 are evenly matched, whereas in previous years there was a difference. Quite a simple question. Should we just think moving forward as buyer growth being a proxy for revenue growth? Or are there anything -- any sort of other issues that you could see that could perhaps sort of disturb that relationship? And the second thing is just on the comment at the end about Turkey coming back, sort of having very good start to the year. Like, could you just give us an idea of how much the like-for-like revenue drag for the whole group came from the weakness in Turkey in 2018?

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: I'll let Dan answer the Turkey question. I'll take the buyer one. I mean, I think, as I said, it's really the best indicator of the strength of the brand, and it is a thing that we focus on the most. And I think it is a very good proxy for revenues, but also I think that it's one you've got to be careful about because it's very easy to add revenue into your business and get a big exhibition. But actually, if you dilute the density of the people on the floor, it can have quite a negative impact on how it feels. So it's one thing that we're really, really focused on in terms of making sure that the revenue and the buyers move in step. The worst-case scenario is for your revenues to move ahead of your buyer growth. If your buyers move ahead of revenue, you'll never hear any complaints from your exhibitors. So you want it that way, right.

DANIEL P. O'BRIEN: In terms of Turkey, I mean, the like-for-like revenue performance was 8% down for the year, and the currency was down 40-odd percent across the year. So combined, over 50% down. In terms of the impacts on the group, marginal, 1%, 2%, that sort of -- that kind of level. So as I mentioned, the group has grown significantly and is doing well and it's kind of grown around that. So it's -- the portfolio effect is really helping us.

IAN RICHARD WHITTAKER: Okay. Sorry, 2 follow-up questions just on that. 1% to 2%, sorry, is that of like-for-like revenue growth impacts or just a profit growth in general?

DANIEL P. O'BRIEN: On the revenue.

IAN RICHARD WHITTAKER: On the revenue, okay. And then, Doug, just in terms of your comments that are saying the worst-case scenario is revenue growth ahead of buyer growth, so therefore, sort of your strategy would be sort of seems quite conservative approach to price increases moving forward?

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Look, I think we're very sensitive to pricing. I mean, everything is transparent in our world. And I think we're in one of the few industries where all of your customers come together in one place and talk. So if you want a riot on your hands, you can actually stick the price up and see what happens. So our strategy has been sort of inflationary. But when you think about pricing, because of the forward nature of the business, we've got to be taking a view of what that is a year out, 18 months out, 2 years out. And we've averaged about 3% to 4%, which obviously is slightly ahead of inflation, and that's where I would see it sort of sticking at. I don't see 10%, and I don't see 0. It's that sort of level.

(inaudible).

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Well, I still think I had never heard of you ask 2 questions rather than 3. I know you guys have 2 more follow-ups. It wasn't meant to be.

Could you give a little bit of color on the replications? It's very helpful the detail provided. But I always thought with the replication strategy. If -- I mean, you tend to know after a year or 2 if something's going to work. And then by year 3, you're starting to make money. But then it really starts to sort of push on 4 and 5. So just in terms of that pace, particularly given the large number of replications in '17 and '18, that really to me suggests a very strong platform for '21 and '22.

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And then a follow-up. I've been a long-term believer in the application of technology for exhibitions in terms of helping people find their most important customers on the exhibition floor, and also for exhibition owners to have a relationship throughout the year or a 2-year cycle rather than just at the time of an exhibition. Can you give us a little bit of color on your thoughts on that?

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Do you want to take any of those?

DANIEL P. O'BRIEN: Yes. So on replication, I mean, you're right in terms of the pattern. I mean, this sort of classic pattern is you launch and you're selling a vision or an idea. What you come around is your second version, you guys you have to show. So that's really tricky. So the key hurdle is getting to the second show, why I'm being successful. And assuming that's successful, you're right, you really start to see the benefits in years 3 and 4. So I think in terms of the patterns we saw in terms of the revenue building and the profitability building, we do see that continuing. And I think we'd hope that should the show be as successful as we expects and plan, that we should see some benefits coming through, you're right, '21 and '22. So that's a good way of thinking about it.

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: And going to the technology point, I mean, I think our industry is really in the foothills in terms of what it's doing with technology. And I think a large part of that has come from it hasn't had a burning platform that other media forms had, and it hasn't had to respond. I think that is changing. I would say it's slowly changing. But I think what we're seeing is certainly, from a marketing perspective, a lot more innovation than from a sales generation perspective. In terms of technology, it has allowed us to market to people in very difficult-to-access places. So historically, if you go back 20 years, very difficult to market in China, very difficult to market in Asia. Now that's changed dramatically. Now I think the next phase that we're seeing is no longer is it good enough to stick 20,000 people in an exhibition hall and hope something happens. So we're seeing a move to actually create those closer relationships physically at the event. And one example of that which we launched for our customers at Labelexpo in Chicago is to use a technology where companies could generate leads from people they actually hadn't interacted with in the stand. Because you go on to a stand, what generally will happen is the salesperson will swipe the badge, they know they've spoken to you, they've captured the details. But that's actually usually quite a low percentile of people who have gone on who are potentially interested in your product. And you probably find that the people who you don't really want to speak to, they actually want to speak to you. So it's a question of how do you capture all of the people who are there who might be interested in your product. So we've put in place a piece of technology where the buyers could go on and they could download information about that company's particular product. So they would touch it, and that would instantly email them PDFs about the product. What that was doing for the customer was generating a hold of leads that they didn't know about who were interested in their products. So in terms of lead generation, we had a 30% increase for our exhibitors in lead generation. So that's just sort of one example of actually how we can make that experience a lot better. And also for us, it gives us ammunition because when we're looking at rebooking, our customers say, well, I never saw anybody, et cetera, et cetera. And then you say, well, actually, you had 5,000 people who downloaded your stuff.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Is that widely (inaudible)?

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Yes. I mean, the technology exists. It's actually owned by a very large corporation. Because one of the other issues that we've got is, because tech is actually quite sort of small, the big tech companies see this as actually not a very interesting industry because actually they're not going to get the returns. So what you've got is a myriad of very, very, small, underfunded tech companies who are trying to make a living, and this particular piece of technology is actually owned by a very large company.

Fiona, I think, was first.

FIONA CATHERINE ORFORD-WILLIAMS, DIRECTOR & SECTOR HEAD MEDIA, EDISON INVESTMENT RESEARCH LIMITED: It's Fiona Orford-Williams from Edison. We're talking about the enlargement of the pipeline. Historically, you've always talked about preferring to work on a partnership basis, getting to know people, all about driving the relationship. Is there a new swathe of opportunities that's coming that you're not already engaging in some respect? And then the second question, because you were talking about this remarkable sort of takeoff on the Bangkok replication, was there something special about that show in that place? Or is Bangkok a new potential really strong hub for you?

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Well, on acquisitions, I think there has been change in dynamics at play. And I think there's -- I think one cannot underestimate the impact of the UBM-Informa transaction in terms of the stimulation. And I think we're also seeing a huge amount of capital trying to get into the market and continuing to want to invest in the market. And I think the dynamics in terms of the major players has changed. So you've gone from a situation where Reed were #1 for 20-odd years and now they're not. And they hadn't made a major acquisition for 15 years and suddenly they have. Assuming that's not extraordinary because it's just when opportunities arise. Then you've got Blackstone who have spent huge amounts of money in the sector, continuing to look to build scale. So at the top end, there are some very interesting dynamics. And then in terms of opportunities, it is still a highly fragmented industry. Informa as #1 have got 6% market share. So there's lots of small, medium-sized businesses out there, but -- that are available. So I think there's a lot of those dynamics coming together. And I think it's creating new opportunities because through necessity, we've got into markets, looked for opportunities, done partnerships. And that's our preferred way of doing it. But I think there's a lot more inbound than us actually working relationships. Definitely, there's been a dynamic change in the last year. All trace back to the Informa-UBM.

In terms of Bangkok, I think this has been a -- it's been the longest overnight success ever. I mean, we've looked at that market for a long, long time. We've tried to get it right. The launch took a lot longer to get to market bluntly than I would have liked. But actually, being patient and the team executing it incredibly professionally has reaped the results. But Bangkok is a very well-established market. It's got very good infrastructure. It is seen as a key hub for that area because of its reach and its airport. And the -- we've deliberately chosen Bangkok to be the launch event of our new Brand Print because of the success we've had with Labelexpo, because of the infrastructure there and the fact that actually we could co-locate it with Labelexpo. And there's a lot of commonality in terms of the buyer groups. So again, it's the sort of dynamics changing and us responding.

Chris?

CHRISTOPHER ANTON GILES COLLETT, RESEARCH ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK AG, RESEARCH DIVISION: It's Chris Collett from Deutsche. I just had 2 questions. One was a quick follow-up on your comments about the acquisition pipeline. Just wondering whether the vendors' expectations on multiples has also moved up. And then second was, have you seen any change in terms of either visitors or exhibitors internationally attending events? Or via some of your business travel events, have you seen any sort of change in people's desire to travel internationally?

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Well, I mean, let's take the last question first. In terms of travel, interestingly we had our major event in Orlando last week in terms of the leisure side, second edition, as I mentioned in the presentation. And a large component of that has been Chinese tour operators who are basically putting big groups of Chinese into the U.S. visit Florida, go to Vegas, whatever. And we saw a doubling from year 1 to year 2 of the Chinese tour operators attending that event. And I think that obviously, with the seemingly changing winds between sort of Trump and President Xi, I think that, that could be quite interesting.

And in terms of vendor multiples, in terms of the large groups, the ones that have transacted, they have been changing hands at increasing multiples. Premiums way above the quoted premiums. And that sort of variation is probably something I can't remember seeing in 26 years of being in the industry. I haven't seen that disparity of multiples. But in the small and medium-sized ones, while multiples have moved a little, they're still in that sort of 7 to sort of 9 range. So they're still at a sensible level where one can actually get value out of them. But it's the bigger portfolios that have moved.

Yes, Gareth?

GARETH RHYS DAVIES, DIRECTOR OF MEDIA EQUITY RESEARCH, NUMIS SECURITIES LIMITED, RESEARCH DIVISION: Yes, Gareth Davis from Numis. Two from me. Just going back to Turkey. Obviously, pretty optimistic commentary in the outlook statement there. Can you just talk about sort of international buyers? Are they coming back? Is it mainly being driven by local? I think there's been a little bit of management change in that business. So is it sort of back on the front foot in terms of -- and then just is it sort of steady-state-sized business now, Turkey, and you're not going to expand further in that market? Or is there organic potential and further sort of M&A? And then secondly, just wondering if you can talk a little bit about U.S. medical and the sort of medium-term prospects there and what your sort of confidence is in being able to continue to deliver mid-single-digit kind of growth in that business.

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Well, Dan, do you want to take the medical point and I'll do the Turkey one?

DANIEL P. O'BRIEN: Yes, I mean, taking the medical first, I mean, we're feeling very good about our medical business. As I mentioned in my section, it covers 4 clinical areas. I don't think they're going to all charge ahead at equal rates. There'll be some going faster than others. But overall, they all look like having they're having a good 2019, and the longer-term outlook in terms of the importance of particularly preventative medicine in the -- in that market generally and the amount of spend that goes into medicine generally in the U.S., all the macro drivers are very positive. So we're feeling quite bullish about the prospects for that business both in terms of 2019 and longer term. And I think that's backed up by the demographics.

GARETH RHYS DAVIES: And just in terms of the competitive backdrop, I mean, I know if we went back sort of 2 to 3 years, there were a lot of low-price players who came in and caused a few issues. But it's not -- it's sort of all settled down now and, again, much more stable.

DANIEL P. O'BRIEN: Yes, I mean, that was specifically really in the antiaging congress -- conference that some -- I don't think -- that has settled down. I mean, the Las Vegas show was fantastic, really good growth in both the exhibitors and attendance. I think there is a well-established platform now for that business because it's so -- because the actual core product is so strong.

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Going to Turkey, on buyers, I mean, it's quite interesting. We've got 2 of our major events coming up in March. So that obviously gives us the confidence to make the stronger comments we've made in the outlook. And what's interesting about those 2 bigger shows, one is in the houseware market, and what we're seeing there is a reorientation of the exhibitor group. We had historically quite a large component of the exhibitor base in the March show who where importers, who will be effectively buying cheaper Chinese product and then reselling them on to retailers in Turkey. What we're seeing now is quite a massive shift in the exhibitor base who are Turkish manufacturers. So it's a made-in-Turkey type event now. Why is that? Because of the depreciation of the currency, it's very attractive in terms of the international market. And as a result, our focus on the marketing is very much bringing in more internationals as well as servicing the domestic market, which is quite a large market. But we're responding to actually how that market has changed to be heavily export orientated. And similarly, we've got Asansor, which is the largest show in the region for lifts, which doesn't sound particularly exciting, but, again, they are big manufacturers of lift components. So the show 2 years ago, one of the largest groups attending the show internationally were from Switzerland, would you believe, to -- and the reason for that is the Swiss industry were going through a massive refurbishment of their lift equipment. And again, that's the type of thing that we see that actually, quite a lot of the big buying comes out of Europe and they're sourcing products that's manufactured in Turkey.

In terms of the business, you're quite right, there's been quite a lot of change in Turkey managerially. We've gone from having multiple businesses where we've had entrepreneurs running them, whether it be on [Aeronaut] or they've owned minorities stakes. And the 3 largest of those, we now own a 100% of. So we've consolidated those 3 businesses under a professional manager, and we're seeing the benefits of that now cycling through, getting proper sales and marketing processes in place.

In terms of would we invest more money in Turkey, I don't think we would buy any more in Turkey, but we're certainly looking at continuing to actually innovate and put new product in the market. I mean, last year, we put our foot into the water with GESS in the education market. That got a very strong support from the Ministry of Education, and that's going to come back this year a lot bigger and a lot stronger with a lot more support from the government. So it's looking for areas where actually we've got expertise and we can add rather than going into sort of new markets.

Ian?

IAN RICHARD WHITTAKER: There's actually 2 follow-up questions. I -- so just something. To stakes. Sort of -- any update what's happening with the concerns happening around opioids. And suddenly slow there. That obviously had been a factor a few years back. That seems to have died down. And then the second thing, I guess, it just comes back to the sort of [Paul's] question on technology, yes, and sort of how you're using that to improve the process for the actual attendees. Yet -- are you going to follow the sort of relics approach sort of where you're saying, we're not going to look to monetize that investment, it would just help to support sort of our general price increases? Or do you think there's any scope there that you could use our technology to add on extra services that could be monetizable?

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: Yes. Do you want to take the opioid?

DANIEL P. O'BRIEN: So, I mean, the opioid crisis hasn't gone away and it won't do quickly. I mean, it actually presents an opportunity for us in terms of the PAINWeek business because if you are a doctor that wants to treat your patients and help them and you want to learn how to do it in a way that isn't going to cause problems with opioid addiction, then where you can go to learn that is PAINWeek. So we're seeing a lot of attracts to that event being around alternative ways of treating chronic pain. And so whilst some of the drug problem was around opioids, we're now seeing a lot of alterative drugs being developed and promoted to address that. So it's actually an opportunity for the business.

JAMES DOUGLAS EMSLIE: I think coming to technology, I think it's going to be a mix of things. I think that, I mean, some of the technologies we will add to get a better customer experience. So for example, at Labelexpo and at Connect, we've added in an expo bot. So basically, you can go and ask the bot basic sort of questions like what time does the conference program start, where are the toilets, et cetera. So we're actually just helping the customer experience, which is obviously something we're not charging for. But probably, sort of 2 areas where there is opportunity to add revenues would be, and we're starting to do this, is using the Connect model, using that sort of technology and understanding where actually, if you're creating value for the customers by actually making scheduled meetings, there's an opportunity to charge for that. So we've started to do that in a smaller way. But actually, if we look at 20-odd years of people trying to make money with technology in our industry, actually the only material revenues that have been made, and certainly this is our experience as well, is on education, is taking physical education and actually putting that online, and people are happy to pay for that. And the best example for us is in the medical business, where people are prepared to pay the same price of getting their education physically online. And for us, the provision of that education online is at a far higher margin because we don't have to provide the facilities and the food, et cetera, et cetera. So -- but I think education is a good area, especially where there's continuing educational regulatory reasons to do that like in medical, like in education itself, et cetera, financial. Thank you very much for coming.
